questions.text: A 40-year-old man is undergoing left-sided nephrectomy for a renal mass. During surgical dissection via a posterior approach, the surgeon identifies the structures surrounding the anterior surface of the left kidney to avoid injury to adjacent viscera. Which of the following viscera is most closely related to the region marked A?
questions.solution:
The given image is the anterior view of the left kidney. The stomach's posterior surface is related to the marked area.
     

  • On the anterosuperior surface of the left kidney, the stomach is one of the key anterior relations.

  • The left kidney is also related anteriorly to the spleen (laterally), pancreas (centrally), and splenic flexure (inferiorly) — but the stomach occupies the most superior anterior relation.

  • Liver and second part of duodenum relate to the right kidney, not the left.






Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1262,1264

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence, especially during activities such as sneezing or lifting heavy objects. She delivered three children vaginally. Pelvic examination reveals mild uterine descent consistent with pelvic organ prolapse. The physician attributes her symptoms to weakening of the pelvic diaphragm, which provides support to the pelvic organs. Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?
A. Iliococcygeus
B. Pubococcygeus
C. Obturator internus
D. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
lliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of 3 muscle components:
  1. Pubococcygeus
         Pubovaginalis – elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
         Puboperinealis – draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
         Puboanalis – elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed

     2. Puborectalis
     3. Iliococcygeus  
 
  • Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces.
  • Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.
  • Levator ani training (Kegel exercises) strengthens these muscles and helps prevent prolapse and incontinence.
 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 25 .

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nucleus is closest to the facial colliculus in depth?
questions.solution:
The facial colliculus is an elevation in the floor of the fourth ventricle, formed by the facial nerve fibers arching over the abducent nucleus.
Thus, in depth, the abducent nucleus lies directly beneath the facial colliculus. 
A lesion here affects the abducent nucleus, causing ipsilateral lateral rectus weakness, leading to inability to abduct the eye and horizontal diplopia.
Larger lesions may also affect the internal genu of the facial nerve, leading to combined abducent and facial nerve palsies (e.g., Millard-Gubler syndrome or Foville syndrome depending on extent).
 

  • Millard-Gubler syndrome: Ipsilateral facial and abducent nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia (ventral pons).

  • Foville syndrome: Ipsilateral facial palsy with conjugate gaze palsy ± contralateral hemiparesis (dorsal pons).

 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 453

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue towards the site of the lesion
Deviation of larynx to the contralateral side during swallowing
Loss of tactile sensation on the tongue on the affected side

questions.text: Find the incorrect statement about total unilateral Hypoglossal nerve injury:
questions.solution:
Hypoglossal nerve is a pure motor nerve and innervates all the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus. Therefore, its transection will not result in loss of tactile sensation of the tongue. 

General sensations from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by lingual nerve which is a branch of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve. Injury to lingual nerve will result in loss of general sensations such as touch, temperature, pressure and pain from anterior 2/3rds of the tongue. 

Note- 

1. Taste sensations from anterior 2/3rds of tongue is carried by chorda tympani nerve, a branch of facial nerve. 

2. Taste as well as general sensations from posterior 1/3rd of tongue is carried by glossopharyngeal nerve. 



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 600

questions.text: Select the muscle that is supplied by the cranial nerve nucleus present beneath the area marked by the arrow below.
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given diagram points towards floor of fourth ventricle and towards Facial Colliculus. 
Facial colliculus is an elevated area located in the dorsal pons.
It is formed by fibres from the facial motor nucleus looping over the abducens(VI) nucleus

The 6th cranial nerve supplies the Lateral Rectus muscle.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 248,453,391

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoes a routine skin biopsy for a pigmented lesion on her forearm. Histological examination is performed, and the following image is obtained. Which type of connective tissue is found in the arrowed area?
questions.solution:
Type of connective tissue present in the reticular dermis is densely irregular (collagen fibers arranged in multiple directions).

This multidirectional orientation is perfect for resisting stress from various angles — crucial in organs like the skin, where mechanical forces are constantly changing.

Dense irregular connective tissue is also present in the capsules of different glands and organs, such as the testis, the sclera of the eye, the periosteum, and the perichondrium, as well as the adventitia of big blood arteries, muscle, and nerves.




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 151,157

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the clinic with numbness over her left ear lobule following a recent cosmetic facial procedure. Which of the following nerves provides sensory supply to the ear lobule?
questions.solution:
The great auricular nerve, a branch of the cervical plexus (C2–C3), provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid region, mastoid area, and the ear lobule. Because it travels superficially across the sternocleidomastoid muscle, it is particularly vulnerable during facial or parotid surgeries.




 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 740
P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 7th edition page no 5

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after falling while hiking. He is unable to abduct his upper limb and has difficulty lifting it above his head. There is no pain, but he notes weakness in the shoulder region. What is the likely root value of the nerve involved ?
questions.solution:
The C5 nerve root is crucial for shoulder abduction. The primary muscle responsible for this action is the deltoid, which is innervated by the axillary nerve (a branch of the brachial plexus). The C5 root is responsible for the motor innervation of the deltoid. When the C5 root is damaged, such as in a traumatic fall or brachial plexus injury, the patient may experience weakness or inability to abduct the arm.

Option 2: 

C6: This root contributes to motor function in the biceps, forearm, and wrist. It helps with elbow flexion and wrist extension, but it does not directly control shoulder abduction.

Option 3:
C4: While it helps with some shoulder elevation and diaphragm innervation, it does not play a central role in shoulder abduction.

Option 4:
C7: This root primarily innervates muscles responsible for elbow extension (e.g., triceps) and wrist flexion/extension. It does not affect shoulder abduction directly.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42 nd Edition Page no 924,925

questions.text: Which of the following jaw movements is controlled by the muscle identified in the following cross section?
questions.solution:
The star pictured above marks the Lateral pterygoid muscle, which connects the lateral
pterygoid plate to the neck of the mandible and the TM joint. It is the only muscle that opens the jaw, and it assists the medial pterygoid muscle in protracting the jaw. (not main function)
Therefore, opening the jaw is the correct response.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 677,678

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman undergoes a total abdominal hysterectomy for endometrial cancer. During the procedure, the surgeon ligates the uterine artery, which arises from the anterior division of the internal iliac artery. Several other arteries arising from the same anterior division are also identified during dissection. Which are the branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?
A. Superior gluteal                       
B. Inferior gluteal                         
C. Superior vesicular                   
D. Vaginal artery                        
E. Inferior vesical
questions.solution:
Memorizing trick:- Posterior division of Internal iliac artery branches-  SIL
Superior Gluteal 
Iliolumbar
Lateral sacral 

Rest all are anterior division branches
Remember as,  IIMOOVU

  • I – Inferior gluteal artery

  • I – Internal pudendal artery

  • M – Middle rectal artery

  • O – Obturator artery

  • O – Obliterated umbilical artery → gives superior vesical arteries

  • V – Vaginal artery (in females) / Inferior vesical artery (in males)

  • U – Uterine artery (in females)


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1309,1464.e80-1464.e82

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with double vision that worsens when looking to the left. On physical examination, when asked to look left, his left eye fails to abduct, while the right eye moves normally. In the diagram, identify the nerve whose palsy causes lateral gaze palsy.
questions.solution:
The sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve), which supplies the lateral rectus muscle, is what causes lateral gaze palsy and it travels within the sinus in close relation with the internal carotid artery.
Hence the answer is option ‘B’

Other options:
A. Occulomotor nerve - Supplies Superior rectus, Inferior rectus, Medial rectus, Inferior oblique, Levator palpebrae
C. Trochlear nerve - Supplies Superior oblique
D. Ophthalmic branch of Maxillary nerve - Sensory supply to Forehead, scalp, upper eyelid, cornea, nose (dorsum), anterior scalp

 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 774

questions.text: Which of the following germ layers gives rise to the intervertebral disc's nucleus pulposus?
questions.solution:
• The nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc is derived from the notochord, which is a midline mesodermal structure (specifically axial mesoderm).

  • It is a remnant of the notochord in the adult.

  • The surrounding annulus fibrosus arises from the sclerotome (from paraxial mesoderm).



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 296,102

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not a mesoderm derivative?
questions.solution:
• The muscular system is made up of skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscle, with the exception of a few types of smooth muscle tissue which are derived from the ectoderm.
  • Certain types of smooth muscle - pupillary, mammary gland, and sweat gland muscles - derive from ectoderm (i.e., sphincter and dilator pupillae, myoepithelial cells).

  • Skeletal muscle: Derived from paraxial mesoderm forming somites (occipital to sacral regions) and somitomeres in the head

  • Tendons: Derived from the sclerotome of somites, attaching muscles to bones.

  • Smooth muscle: Derived from the splanchnic layer of lateral plate mesoderm, surrounding the gut.

  • Cardiac muscle: Derived from the splanchnic mesoderm surrounding the heart tube.

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 163,164

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of localized tenderness in the infraclavicular fossa, which he noticed after an intense workout. On examination, the patient reports that the pain increases when he raises his arm. You begin palpating the area to assess the structure that may be causing the discomfort. Which of the following scapula components can be palpated inside the infraclavicular fossa?
questions.solution:
A- Superior angle
B- Choracoid process
C- Acromion 
D- Glenoid cavity
 

  • Coracoid process is palpated inside infraclavicular fossa
    The coracoid process is a bony projection located on the anterior surface of the scapula, just beneath the clavicle.

  • It serves as an attachment point for several important muscles, including:

    • Pectoralis minor

    • Coracobrachialis

    • Short head of the biceps brachii

    • The coracoacromial ligament also attaches here.


Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 787,803

questions.text: Injury to the marked structure in the given cadaveric image will result in
questions.solution:
The specimen shown in the image represents the cubital fossa, with the radial nerve (marked as the lateral-most structure) being implicated. The radial nerve is a critical nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the wrist, forearm, and hand, including the muscles responsible for extending the wrist and fingers.

A midshaft fracture of the humerus is a common cause of radial nerve injury because the radial nerve travels along the posterior aspect of the humerus. This injury can lead to the loss of function in the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, resulting in a condition known as wrist drop.

Wrist Drop: This occurs due to paralysis of the wrist extensors (such as the extensor carpi radialis and extensor digitorum), leading to an inability to extend the wrist, which causes it to remain in a flexed position.

Option 1: Ape thumb deformity occurs due to median nerve injury, resulting in the loss of thumb opposition and the thumb remaining in a flexed position.
Option 2: Claw hand is caused by ulnar nerve injury, leading to hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints in the fourth and fifth fingers.
Option 4: Claudication is not a nerve injury but is caused by peripheral artery disease. Claudication in the upper limb is rare but can occur due to subclavian artery stenosis or thoracic outlet syndrome.
 

Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice 42 and edition Page no 887,1464.e37-1464.e39

questions.text: Please accurately identify the region marked "E" in the electron micrograph of the sarcomere that is shown below:
questions.solution:
The area marked as "E" in the illustration is the lighter and Isotropic band, called the I-band.

It contains a dark demarcation, Z-line at its centre.

A : A-band
B : Actin filaments
C: Sarcomere’s width
D: H-zone

 

  • A-band: The A-band is the region that contains the full length of the thick filaments (myosin). It appears dark on an electron micrograph due to the overlap of thin (actin) and thick (myosin) filaments.

  • I-band: The I-band is the region containing only thin filaments (actin). It is lighter in appearance and is bisected by the Z-line.

  • M-band: The M-band is located in the center of the sarcomere, holding the thick filaments in place. It does not change in length during contraction.

  • H-zone: The H-zone is the region within the A-band where there is no overlap between the thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments. It only contains thick filaments and is lighter than the A-band.

      P



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 101

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness and difficulty with speech. A CT scan reveals an ischemic stroke. Which cells of the human body are most sensitive to ischemia?
questions.solution:
Neurons are the cells of the human body that are most sensitive to ischemia, which refers to a lack of oxygen and nutrients due to decreased blood flow to a particular tissue or organ. Neurons require a constant supply of oxygen and glucose to function properly, and even a brief interruption of blood flow can cause irreversible damage. Other cells, such as nephrons in the kidneys, cardiac myocytes in the heart, and hepatocytes in the liver, are also sensitive to ischemia, but neurons are the most vulnerable.

Neurons > Cardiac myocytes > Renal tubular cells > Hepatocytes > Skeletal muscle > Adipose tissue
This order reflects the susceptibility of these tissues to ischemia, with neurons being the most sensitive and adipose tissue the least.

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 134

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic following a long international flight. He reports being seated for over 10 hours without much movement during the journey. What is the most serious complication of prolonged sitting?
questions.solution:
Following are the Complications of Prolonged sitting posture-
a. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
b. Pressure sores of the
c. Muscle contractures
d. Deconditioning of the cardiovascular system.

Prolonged sitting, especially during long-haul flights, significantly increases the risk of venous thromboembolism, which includes conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Inactivity during long flights promotes stasis of blood flow in the veins, increasing the likelihood of clot formation. This is the most serious complication and can be life-threatening if a clot travels to the lungs (PE).
To prevent the complication, low- dose heparin or non-pharmacologic means like graduated compression stockings should be used.


 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 132

choices.text: Alpha motor neurons are activated first followed by gamma motor neurons
Gamma motor neurons are activated first followed by alpha motor neurons

questions.text: Which statement about alpha and gamma motor neurons during the initiation of voluntary movements is correct?
questions.solution:
Alpha motor neurons are responsible for the direct activation of skeletal muscles, causing them to contract. These neurons innervate the extrafusal fibers of the muscle, which generate the force for voluntary movements.

Gamma motor neurons control the intrafusal fibers of the muscle spindle, which are involved in adjusting the sensitivity of the muscle spindle to changes in muscle length. This helps maintain muscle tone and ensures proper proprioception during movement.

Both alpha as well as gamma motor neurons fire in response to excitatory input from spinal motor circuits.
Intrafusal and extrafusal fibers contract concurrently as a result of this "a—y coactivation," allowing spindle afferent activity to continue throughout the duration of muscle contraction.
By doing this, the spindle maintains its capacity to react to stretch and reflexively modify a-motor neuron discharge.




Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 236,237

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic for preoperative assessment before undergoing an elective surgery. The surgeon orders coagulation tests, including prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), to assess her bleeding risk. What is the preferred anticoagulant for coagulation tests?
questions.solution:
Trisodium citrate(option 1) is the anticoagulant of choice for coagulation tests. The most commonly used anticoagulant for in vitro coagulation studies is citric acid. It is generally employed in the form of sodium citrate. 
Trisodium citrate binds calcium ions in the blood, which are essential for the coagulation cascade to occur. By binding calcium, trisodium citrate prevents clot formation without interfering with the coagulation factors, making it ideal for PT, aPTT, and fibrinogen testing.
The 3.2% concentration is specifically recommended because it provides the correct ratio of blood to anticoagulant for accurate results.



 
 

Reference: Dacie and Lewis Practical Haematology 11th Edition Page no 4,5

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male with a history of hypertension undergoes an electrocardiogram (ECG) as part of a routine cardiac check-up. What will be the sequence of cardiac events after the P wave ?

A. a wave
B. 1st heart sound
C. Filling of ventricles
D. T wave
questions.solution:
The correct sequence on cardiac cycle is  3. A -> C -> B - > D. 
Amongst given option correct answer would be a wave ->Ventricular filling ->1st heart sound ->T wave
 

  • A wave: After the P wave, the a wave on JVP occurs, which represents atrial contraction. This follows the depolarization of the atria (P wave), leading to the contraction of the atria and the push of blood into the ventricles.

  • Filling of ventricles: After the a wave, the ventricles fill with blood following the atrial contraction.(NOTE: 70% of ventricular filling is passive - only about 30% is due to atrial contraction)

  • 1st heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) occurs when the AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) close, signaling the beginning of ventricular systole.

  • T wave: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs much later, after the ventricular contraction (systole) has finished.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529,530

questions.solution:
True statement is that

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is undergoing pulmonary function testing to evaluate chronic dyspnea. A pressure-volume loop is generated during the test. The pulmonologist notes that the inspiratory and expiratory phases of the loop do not follow the same trajectory. What causes a difference in the curve's trajectories for the inspiratory and expiratory loops?
questions.solution:
The curves produced during inflation and deflation show differences. Hysteresis is the name given to this variation, which is noticeably absent from the curves produced by saline. Hysteresis is influenced by the alveolar environment, particularly the produced substances that lower surface tension and prevent alveoli from collapsing.

Why this happens?

  • Pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II alveolar cells, reduces surface tension in the alveoli.

  • During inspiration, the alveoli expand and new surfactant molecules are spread across the surface — but this process lags slightly behind alveolar expansion.

  • During expiration, the alveoli recoil, and surfactant is more concentrated on the smaller alveolar surface, making expiration easier and more efficient.

  • This difference in surfactant concentration and action between inspiration and expiration contributes significantly to the hysteresis loop.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 619,620

questions.text: Which part is responsible for the formation of the macula densa?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is a part of Distal tubule.

Macula densa cells are strategically positioned in the distal tubule (part of juxtaglomerular apparatus) with their apical membrane exposed to the tubular fluid, whereas their basilar aspects are in contact with cells of the mesangium and the afferent arteriole. They sense the Na+ concentration and take part in Tubulo-glomerular feedback. Based on the NaCl levels, they signal the juxtaglomerular (JG) cells in the afferent arteriole to release renin, playing a vital role in blood pressure and fluid balance regulation via the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 662

questions.text: The term for a nerve injury that results in the severing of axons while leaving the outer nerve sheath intact is:
questions.solution:
In axonotmesis, the axon of nerve is injured but with intact nerve sheath.
Axonotmesis refers to a nerve injury in which the axon is severed, but the connective tissue layers (endoneurium, perineurium, epineurium) remain intact. This allows for potential regeneration of the axon along the original path. It's commonly seen in crush injuries. Can heal spontaneously but sometimes require surgical repair depending on the injury.

Option 2: Neuropraxia: Temporary conduction block without axonal damage (e.g., mild compression); complete recovery expected.
Option 3: Neurotmesis: The most severe type — complete disruption of the axon and connective tissue; no spontaneous recovery. Surgical repair is necessary.
Option 4: Axonopraxia: Not a real term — distractor in the options.






Preference : https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22608-neuropraxia

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with lethargy, irritability, and increased wwork of breathing. On examination, the child appears pale with hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show elevated lactate, uric acid, and triglyceride levels, with minimal urinary ketones. A diagnosis of Von Gierke disease is considered. Which of the following is not responsible for ketosis in a patient with Von Gierke disease?
questions.solution:
Von Gierke disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) leads to hypoglycemia due to a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase. Despite severe hypoglycemia (options 1 and 2), ketone production is impaired. This is partly because oxaloacetate is diverted toward gluconeogenesis (option 3), limiting its availability for the TCA cycle, favoring ketogenesis. However, fat mobilization is actually increased, not decreased. Hence, option 4 is incorrect, making it the right answer to this question.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman undergoing evaluation for a genetic disorder has a blood sample sent for PCR analysis. This test involves amplification of DNA to identify specific genetic mutations. Which of the following is the correct order of steps in  polymerase chain reaction (PCR)?
questions.solution:
The process of polymerase chain reaction involves Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

A. Denaturation - Separation of DNA by melting through 94 C for 3 minutes.
- Converts double stranded DNA to single stranded DNA

B. Annealing - Hybridization of two oligonucleotides used as primers to the target DNA to form template-primer hybridization complex. 
-At 3’end at 54C for 45seconds

C. Extension - Elongation of DNA chain by nucleotide addition from the primers
- Using DNA polymerase as catalyst in the presence of Mg2+ ions - At 72 C for 2 mins



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 452.

choices.text: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 3’ UTR
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is increased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 5’ UTR
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 5’ UTR
Ferritin translation is increased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 5’ UTR

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about intracellular regulation of iron metabolism
questions.solution:
Option(3) is correct.

Iron metabolism in cells is tightly regulated by Iron Regulatory Proteins (IRPs) that bind to Iron-Responsive Elements (IREs) on mRNA of iron-related proteins depending on cellular iron levels.

When iron concentration is low
  • IRP(iron regulatory protein) binds to the 3' IRE (iron responsive element) and stabilize the mRNA for Tfr (transferrin receptor), increasing its translation  and allowing Tfr synthesis. (Hence, option 1 is incorrect. Option 2 is incorrect because IRP does not bind to 5' UTR of Tfr)
  • IRP binds to 5' IRE of ferritin prevents mRNA to synthesise ferritin (i.e. decreases Ferritin translation) - therefore option 3 is correct. 
When iron concentration is High
  • IRP dissociate from 3' IRE on transferrin receptor and lack of IRP causes decreased Tfr synthesis.
  • IRP dissociate from 5'IRE of Ferritin to allow mRNA to synthesise ferritin.(ie increase Ferritin)(therefore option 4 is incorrect - ferritin translation is not increased by binding of IRP to 5')


MNEMONIC: 

  • “Ferritin is Fast-blocked” at the 5' end by IRP in low iron.

  • “Transferrin is Tail-protected” at the 3' end by IRP in low iron.


Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 458.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of calf pain and fatigue during physical activity, such as playing soccer. He reports that the discomfort resolves with rest. Physical examination is unremarkable at rest. A muscle biopsy demonstrates excessive glycogen accumulation within the myocytes. What type of enzyme deficit is most likely?
questions.solution:
Type V Glycogen Storage Disease (Muscle Phosphorylase Deficiency, McArdle Disease): GSD V is caused by the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase activity. Lack of this enzyme limits muscle ATP generation by glycogenolysis, resulting in muscle glycogen accumulation, and is the prototype of muscle energy disorders. Deficiency of myophosphorylase impairs the cleavage of glucosyl molecules from the straight chain of glycogen.

Symptoms are generally characterized by exercise intolerance with muscle cramps and pain. Two types of activity tend to cause symptoms: brief exercise of great intensity, such as sprinting or carrying heavy loads; and less intense but sustained activity, such as climbing stairs or walking uphill.

Option 1. Muscle debranching enzyme: Seen in Cori disease (Type III GSD). Affects both liver and muscle; not as exercise-specific and usually involves hepatomegaly.

Option 2. Phosphofructokinase I: Associated with Tarui disease (GSD Type VII). Also causes exercise intolerance, but less common than McArdle’s.

Option 3. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Seen in Von Gierke disease (Type I GSD) — primarily affects the liver, causes severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly, not exercise-induced myopathy.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

choices.text: Which of the following reactions does not occur in vitamin B12 deficiency?

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, numbness in her hands and feet, and difficulty walking. Blood tests reveal macrocytic anemia, elevated homocysteine levels, and low vitamin B12. Which of the following reactions does not occur in vitamin B12 deficiency?
A. Methionine Synthase
B. Methyl Malonyl CoA Mutase
C. Glutathione peroxidase
D. Folate reductase
questions.solution:
B12-Dependent Enzymes are as follows-

1. Methionine synthase (methylcobalamin)
Homocysteine -> Methionine

2. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase (adenosylcobalamin)
L methyl malonyl coa -> Succinyl coa

3. Leucine aminomutase (adenosylcobalamin)
L-leucine -> β-leucine


 

Glutathione peroxidase – This requires selenium, not vitamin B12.

Folate reductase (dihydrofolate reductase) – This uses folate, not B12, although there's a functional folate trap in B12 deficiency.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 536.

questions.text:
Alternate splicing occurs in a gene with segments 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and a primer with the letters w, x, y, and z. It produces two goods, A and B.



Which primers are used to yield product A?
questions.solution:
In the context of alternative splicing, different combinations of exons (segments 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) can be included or excluded in the mature mRNA. The primers (w, x, y, z) will bind to the corresponding regions in the gene to amplify specific products based on the splicing pattern.

To determine which primers yield product A, we need to consider how alternative splicing affects the selection of exons and the corresponding primer pairs.

Product A includes segment 1,3,4 and 5 in its structure.

Seg 1- Needs to be transcribed, so W is essential
Seg 2- Doesn't need to be transcribed
Seg 3- Needs to be transcribed, so Y is essential
Seg 4- Requires promotor Z but not essential since promotor Y can continue the transcription as indicated by the arrow.

Therefore, the answer is promotor W and Y.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 399.

questions.text: The nucleus is where the receptor for hormone X is determined to be located. What could possibly be X?
questions.solution:
• Thyroxine (TH) is a lipophilic hormone that acts on nuclear receptor.
  • “Steroids and thyroid hormones are distinguished by their predominantly intracellular sites of action, since they can diffuse freely through the cell membrane."
  • They bind to a family of largely cytoplasmic proteins known as nuclear receptors. Upon ligand binding, the receptor–ligand complex translocates to the nucleus where it either homodimerizes, or associates with a distinct liganded nuclear receptor to form a heterodimer. In either case, the dimer binds to DNA to either increase or decrease gene transcription in the target tissue.




Key points: 

  • Intracellular receptors: Typically bind to lipophilic (fat-soluble) hormones like thyroid hormones, cortisol, estrogen, testosterone, and progesterone.

  • Surface receptors: Involved in the action of peptide hormones like insulin, FSH, adrenaline, growth hormone, and prolactin.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 482.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with sickle cell disease presents for a routine check-up. Genetic testing reveals that his hemoglobin is of the HbS type, which results from a point mutation where valine substitutes glutamic acid. If his hemoglobin is analyzed using gel electrophoresis, how does the mobility of HbS compare to regular hemoglobin (HbA)?
questions.solution:
Due to the absence of the negatively charged glutamate residues in the two chains, HbS is less negatively charged than HbA, which causes the reduced mobility of HbS in sickle cells.
 

  • Normal Hemoglobin (HbA): HbA contains glutamic acid at position 6 of the beta-globin chain. Glutamic acid is a negatively charged amino acid. Under standard conditions, HbA will migrate towards the positive electrode in an electric field due to its negative charge.

  • Sickle Cell Hemoglobin (HbS): In HbS, glutamic acid at position 6 is replaced by valine, which is a hydrophobic (non-polar) amino acid. This change reduces the negative charge of the hemoglobin molecule compared to HbA. As a result, HbS has a lower negative charge than HbA. In alkaline electrophoresis, which is commonly used, HbS will migrate more slowly than HbA because it is less negatively charged, and thus it does not move as far towards the anode as HbA does.




Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 54.

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is studying a new protein biomarker in the lab. To purify it from serum samples, he considers various protein precipitation techniques. Which of the following is not a protein precipitation technique?
questions.solution:
Titration with reducing sugar is NOT a method for protein precipitation

Protein precipitation can be done by following methods:
1.Isoelectric method
2.Salting in and salting out
3.Precipitation method
4.Using heavy metals
5.Chromatographic methods
 
  • Option 1: Trichloroacetic acid is a strong acid that denatures proteins by disrupting hydrogen bonds and altering pH, making it a classic method of protein precipitation.
  • Option 2: Alcohol precipitation, using ethanol or methanol, reduces the solubility of proteins by dehydrating them, leading to their aggregation and precipitation.
  • Option 3: The isoelectric point method involves adjusting the pH to the protein’s isoelectric point, where it carries no net charge and becomes least soluble, causing it to precipitate out of solution.
However, Option 4 - titration with reducing sugar is not used for protein precipitation. It is typically part of tests for detecting reducing sugars like glucose or fructose, such as Benedict’s or Fehling’s test, and has no role in protein isolation.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: Match the following conditions
questions.solution:
Mnemonic: "Very Poor Carbohydrate Metabolism Hurts Liver & Muscles"
 

  1. V – Von Gierke (Type I)

  2. P – Pompe (Type II)

  3. C – Cori (Type III)

  4. M – McArdle (Type V)

  5. H – Hers (Type VI)

  6. L – Liver affected in Andersen (Type IV)

  7. M – Muscle PFK deficiency in Tarui (Type VII)

Quick tip: 

  • Even numbers (II, IV, VI) often affect liver/cardiac systems.

  • Odd numbers (I, III, V, VII) involve muscle/glucose metabolism.



Reference: Vasudevan textbook of Biochemistry, 8th Edition, Page No 144.

questions.text: Which of the following best illustrates how an enzyme-catalyzed process changes its free energy?
questions.solution:
B reaction is an enzyme catalyzed reaction.

A is the curve of the normal reaction, requiring a certain amount of activation energy.

By using a catalyst(enzyme), this barrier of activation energy comes down and the curve appears similar to B.

Key concept: 

  • Enzymes lower the activation energy (Ea) of a reaction.

  • They do NOT change the overall free energy change (ΔG) of the reaction.

  • The reaction equilibrium remains unchanged; enzymes just help reach it faster.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 72.

questions.text: What is CAP in LAC operon an example of?
questions.solution:
The catabolite activator protein (CAP), also known as cAMP receptor protein (CRP), is a positive regulator of the lac operon.

  • When glucose is low, cAMP increases, binding to CAP.

  • The CAP-cAMP complex binds upstream of the lac operon promoter and enhances transcription by increasing RNA polymerase affinity.

This is classic positive regulation, as it promotes gene expression when glucose is scarce and lactose is present.





Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 423.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless, slow-growing mass in the region of the left parotid gland. Imaging confirms a well-circumscribed lesion, and fine-needle aspiration reveals features consistent with a pleomorphic adenoma. Which of the following is not seen in pleomorphic adenoma
questions.solution:
• Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized by the presence of myoepithelial cells and chondroid differentiation, but it does not typically exhibit perineural invasion.
  • Perineural invasion refers to the infiltration of tumor cells into the nerve fibers. It is commonly associated with malignant salivary gland tumors, particularly: Adenoid cystic carcinoma & Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Keratin pearls are also not seen, but since perineural invasion indicates malignancy, it's even more clearly incorrect in a benign tumor.
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 748, 751 .

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 2, presents to the emergency department 5 days after a normal vaginal delivery with complaints of worsening headache and nausea. The headache is described as dull and constant, with intermittent episodes of vomiting. She denies any visual changes, fever, or neck stiffness. On examination, her vital signs are stable, and she appears well-hydrated. Neurological examination reveals papilledema on fundoscopy, but no focal neurological deficits. She has no history of trauma. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cortical vein thrombosis
 
  • The most likely diagnosis for the woman who had a normal vaginal delivery and presented with headache/vomiting and papilledema visible in the fundus is cortical vein thrombosis.
  • Cortical vein thrombosis is a form of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) where blood clots form in the veins draining the cerebral cortex.
  • It can lead to increased intracranial pressure, resulting in symptoms such as headache, vomiting, and visual disturbances.

Option 2 - Meningitis: Presents with headache, vomiting, and papilledema, but typically includes fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status, which are absent here.

Option 3 - Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH): Causes sudden, severe headache ("worst headache of my life") with nausea and vomiting. Papilledema is a late finding, and the acute onset makes CVT more likely.

Option 4 - Acute migraine: Causes headache and vomiting, but papilledema is not associated. The patient also lacks typical visual aura and photophobia, and migraines are rare postpartum.



Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 3342.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a painless, firm mass in his left testicle. On examination, the testis is enlarged, and the mass is well-defined. Ultrasound shows a hypoechoic mass, and serum tumor markers are ordered. Which of the following tumor markers is most likely elevated in this patient with a seminoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PLAP

Tumor marker for seminoma is PLAP

Tumor marker for seminoma is PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase) but beta-HCG can also increased in around 5-10% cases of pure seminoma, as they contain syncytiotrophoblast-like giant cells.

  • LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): Can also be elevated in seminomas but is a less specific marker.

  • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): Typically elevated in non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (e.g., embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumors) but not in seminomas.

  • HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): Can be elevated in ~10% seminomas, especially in more advanced cases, but PLAP is much more specific for seminomas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 970.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is diagnosed with idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) after failing to respond to high-dose steroids over several weeks. The patient’s history is significant for recurrent episodes of edema and proteinuria. Which of the following gene deficiencies is most frequently associated with idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) NPHS-2
 
  • The most common gene defect in idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is NPHS-2 (which codes for podocin) Mutations in NPHS2 result in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Affected children usually show pathologic features of FSGS.
  • A distinctive pattern of autosomal recessive FSGS results from mutations in the NPHS2 gene, which maps to chromosome 1q25–q31 and encodes the protein product podocin. Podocin has also been localized to the slit diaphragm. Mutations in NPHS2 result in a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset.
  • Mutations in the gene encoding the podocyte actin-binding protein α-actinin 4 underlie some cases of autosomal dominant FSGS, which can be insidious in onset but has a high rate of progression to renal insufficiency
Other options: 
  • Option 1: ACE (Angiotensin-converting enzyme) gene is not directly related to SRNS, though ACE inhibitors are used to manage proteinuria in nephrotic syndrome.
  • Option 3: HOX-11 gene is related to certain cancers e.g. T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) and not involved in nephrotic syndrome.
  • Option 4: PAX gene mutations are implicated in nephrotic syndrome in some syndromic forms but are less commonly associated with idiopathic SRNS compared to NPHS-2.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an autoimmune disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Option 1 - Ulcerative colitis
 

  • Ulcerative colitis (UC): While UC is often considered an autoimmune-like condition due to its chronic inflammatory nature, it is not officially classified as an autoimmune disorder. It is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), which involves immune system dysfunction but it is not primarily an autoimmune disease.

  • Grave’s disease: Autoimmune disorder, where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, leading to hyperthyroidism.

  • Rheumatoid arthritis: Autoimmune disorder characterized by immune-mediated inflammation of the joints.

  • SLE (Systemic lupus erythematosus): Autoimmune disorder involving multiple organ systems, including skin, kidneys, and joints.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 799.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is scheduled for an elective cholecystectomy. Preoperative blood work is ordered, including electrolyte levels to assess his kidney function and overall metabolic status. Which anticoagulant from the list below is used to estimate electrolytes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lithium Heparin 
 
  • Lithium heparin is the anticoagulant used for electrolyte estimation- it's the anticoagulant in a green-colored vacutainer.
  • EDTA is typically used in hematological tests (e.g., complete blood count). Because EDTA causes in vitro hemolysis (which might lead to spurious electrolyte values), lithium-heparin is the preferred anticoagulant for electrolyte measurement. 
  • Citrate is mainly used for coagulation studies and is not recommended for electrolyte analysis.
  • Sodium fluoride is used primarily to preserve glucose in blood samples, not for electrolyte measurement.



Online Reference: Bayot ML, Tadi P. Laboratory Tube Collection. [Updated 2023 Aug 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555991/

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after being stung by a bee. She is experiencing symptoms of anaphylaxis, including difficulty breathing, swelling, and hypotension. Identify the antibody that is causing this reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) IgE

  • The given history is suggestive of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction to a bee sting. It is mediated by Ig E antibody.
  • Type I hypersensitivity involves immunoglobulin E (IgE) mediated release of antibodies against the soluble antigen.
  • This results in mast cell degranulation and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.
  • Most immediate hypersensitivity (Type I) disorders are caused by excessive Th2 responses, and these cells play a central role by stimulating IgE production and promoting inflammation.
  • When a mast cell armed with IgE antibodies previously produced in response to an antigen is exposed to the same antigen, the cell is activated, leading to the release of an arsenal of powerful mediators that are responsible for immediate hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (e.g., the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g., peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g., those in bee venom).


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 205.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent, painless swelling of lymph nodes in the neck and unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months. A lymph node biopsy is performed to investigate the possibility of lymphoma. Immunohistochemical staining is ordered to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following markers is most likely to be positive in lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Leukocyte common antigen

Lymphoma marker is leukocyte common antigen (CD 45).
Normal lymphocytes as well as the majority of lymphoproliferative disorders/leukemia/lymphoma express LCA (leukocyte common antigen) or CD45 strongly.

Other options: - 
  • S-100 and HMB-45 are markers of melanocytes 
  • Cytokeratin is a marker of epithelial neoplasm

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 593.

choices.text: Waldeyer's ring is the most common site of Hodgkin's Lymphoma
Mixed cellularity is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma
Reed sternberg cells are positive for CD30 and PAX5

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and intermittent low-grade fever, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss over the last two months. She is diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following statements is true regarding Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• Most common sites to be involved in Hodgkin's lymphoma are cervical and clavicular lymph nodes.
  • Mixed cellularity is more common in older adults and in HIV-positive patients, but not the most common overall.
  • Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma with good prognosis and presents as a mediastinal mass in young patients.
  • Reed sternberg cells are of B cell origin and are positive for CD 30 and PAX5 markers.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 611-616.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of facial puffiness and frothy urine. He denies hematuria or recent illness. Physical examination reveals periorbital edema and mild lower limb edema. Urinalysis shows proteinuria (+4), and his serum albumin is significantly decreased. A kidney biopsy is performed. Direct immunofluorescence and electron microscopy images from a kidney biopsy are presented below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Membranous glomerulopathy
 
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is the most likely diagnosis. 
  • Direct immunofluorescence shows granular IgG and C3 deposition along the glomerular basement membrane.

  • Electron microscopy reveals subepithelial immune complex deposits and "spike and dome" appearance of the GBM.

  • Membranous glomerulopathy is an autoimmune kidney disease where the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the glomerular basement membrane. This leads to thickening of the membrane and impaired kidney function.
Other options: 
  • Option 2: Membranoproliferative GN: Would have mesangial hypercellularity, double-contour (tram-track) GBM, and low complement levels.

  • Option 3: Minimal change disease: Would show normal LM, negative IF, and effacement of podocyte foot processes (but no immune deposits).

  • Option 4: FSGS: Would show segmental sclerosis on LM; not granular IF or subepithelial spikes.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, brittle nails, and occasional dizziness. She mentions that her menstrual periods are heavy and prolonged. Physical examination reveals pallor and angular cheilitis. Her laboratory workup shows a microcytic hypochromic anemia.Which of the following is not reduced in iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) TIBC

Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) is increased in iron deficiency anemia.
In case of iron deficiency anemia since the relative free transferrin concentration is high; it is potentially able to bind to more amounts of iron, hence TIBC increases.

* Trick- Two 'Ts' increase in iron deficiency anemia- TIBC and soluble transferrin receptors. Remaining parameters of iron metabolism decrease. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 751.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with altered mental status, asterixis, and confusion. He is diagnosed with hepatic encephalopathy. Which of the following statements applies to a person with advanced liver disease?
(i) Hyperammonemia
(ii) Low ATP production
(iii) Conversion of alpha-keto glutarate to glutamate and then to glutamine is increased
(iv) Alpha-keto glutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) i, ii & iii

  • (i) Hyperammonemia: Due to impaired urea cycle function in the failing liver, ammonia accumulates in blood → leads to encephalopathy.

  • (ii) Low ATP production: Damaged hepatocyte mitochondria result in impaired oxidative phosphorylation.

  • (iii) Increased conversion of α-ketoglutarate to glutamate to glutamine: The body attempts to detoxify ammonia by converting it into glutamine via glutamine synthetase, which uses α-ketoglutarate, depleting it from the TCA cycle.

  • (iv) Alpha-ketoglutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation: This occurs in normal metabolism, but in liver failure, α-KG is diverted to glutamine synthesis instead.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2549.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of early satiety, vague abdominal discomfort, and a 4.5 kg unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months. A contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals a well-defined submucosal mass arising from the stomach wall. Endoscopic biopsy shows spindle-shaped tumor cells, and immunohistochemistry is ordered for further characterization. Which of the following markers is most specific for diagnosing a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)?
questions.solution:
• DOG1 and CD117 are the most sensitive markers for GIST.
  • GIST also expresses CD34, SDH,PDGF receptor A.
  • S100 is a marker for melanoma.
  • CA15-3 is a marker for breast cancer.
  • NRG-1 highly expressed in papillary carcinoma thyroid

 Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic for a routine gynecological examination. She is sexually active and has no significant medical history. As part of the evaluation, a cervical smear is obtained to screen for cervical dysplasia and carcinoma. Which stain is used for making Cervical smears?
questions.solution:
Papanicolau stain is used to stain Cervical smear. It is a Polychrome stain that stain different types of cells with different colors to identify abnormal cells.

The Pap stain uses multiple dyes to differentiate various cell components. The main components of the stain include:

  1. Eosin: Stains cytoplasm pink and helps visualize cell outlines.

  2. Hematoxylin: Stains the nucleus blue, helping to highlight nuclear morphology.

  3. Orange G: Stains keratin and other cytoplasmic components orange.


 
Fig: Papanicolaou Stain.
 

Other stains:

  • Cresyl blue – used for reticulocyte counts.

  • Methylene blue – used for general-purpose staining, not specific to cervical smears.

  • Giemsa stain – used in hematology and for detecting parasites like malaria.



Reference: Sathawane P, Kamal MM, Deotale PR, Mankar H. Nuances of the Papanicolaou stain. Cytojournal. 2022 Jun 14;19:43. doi: 10.25259/CMAS_03_18_2021. PMID: 35928529; PMCID: PMC9345133.

questions.text: Which is the most reactive free radical?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Hydroxyl

  • Hydroxyl radical is the most potent Reactive Oxygen Species in vivo. 
  • Hydroxyl radical is particularly unstable and is the most reactive of the free radical molecules.
  • In addition, it is capable of reacting rapidly and non-specifically with most biological molecule.
  • H2O2 + e- → OH + OH- (Hydroxyl radical)

Other radicals:

  • Peroxide (O²): Less reactive compared to hydroxyl radicals but can cause damage under certain conditions.

  • Carboxyl radical (•COOH): Less commonly involved in cellular oxidative stress compared to hydroxyl radicals.

  • Superoxide (O•): It is reactive but is not as damaging as the hydroxyl radical. It is often converted to hydrogen peroxide (HO) by the enzyme superoxide dismutase.

Remember, Hydroxyl radical (•OH) > Superoxide (O•) > Peroxide (HO) > Carboxyl radical (•COOH) in reactivity.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 83.
Online Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3911811/pdf/JRI-14-158.pdf

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with pain in the lower limb. X ray showed a lesson at the tibial diaphysis with reactions visible on the surface of the bone. Histopathology of the lesion showed small round cells, the lesion is positive for MIC2 on immunohistochemistry. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical stem and histopathology/IHC description matches Ewing's sarcoma. (Diaphyseal tumor in an adolescent boy having Small round Blue cell histopathology and MIC2 positivity)

Ewing's Sarcoma 
  • The histopathology of Ewing sarcoma is characterized by the presence of small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. (It's a Small round Blue cell tumor). Necrosis and mitotic figures are commonly seen.
  • The following IHC markers are commonly used for Ewing sarcoma:
  1. CD99(Also known as MIC2): This is the most sensitive marker(but not specific) for Ewing sarcoma. It is positive in more than 90% of cases.
  2. FLI-1
  3. NKX2.2: More specific than CD99 for Ewing's Sarcoma. 
  • The combination of CD99/NKX2.2 is very specific for Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Osteosarcoma typically occurs in the metaphysis of long bones and does not usually show small round cells on histopathology, nor does it typically test positive for MIC2.

  • Neuroendocrine tumor metastasis may present similarly, but it is less likely to show a primary bone lesion with positive MIC2 staining.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 1192,1193, 1188,477,478.

questions.text:
Match the following
Column I  Column II
1 KIT A Myeloproliferative disorders
2 KRAS B Lung cancer
3 JAK 2 C Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs)
4 ALK D Pancreatic cancer
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is 1-C 2-D 3-A 4-B.
 

  • KIT is a receptor tyrosine kinase and is commonly associated with Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs).

  • KRAS mutations are frequently found in Pancreatic cancer, among other malignancies.

  • JAK 2 mutations are characteristic of Myeloproliferative disorders such as polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia.

  • ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) gene rearrangements are associated with Lung cancer, particularly non-small cell lung carcinoma.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page. No- 285.

choices.text: Enlarged breasts, increased hair all over the body

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who smoked 5 packs a day for 11 years has been diagnosed with lung cancer. The tumor was shown to have tiny, highly mitotic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei through histologic analysis. Which of the following clinical manifestations could the patient experience while they are ill?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thin limbs and obese trunks
 
  • The biopsy of the patient, who is a 60-year-old male with a history of 55 pack years and presented with chronic cough, revealed small hyperchromatic nuclei and highly mitotic cells–findings which are suggestive of Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC).
  • Small cell carcinoma is comprised of relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell cancer lungs- SIADH, Cushing's syndrome(given in the question), Lambert-Eaton syndrome, anemia, etc.

  • Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC), which is known for producing ectopic hormones such as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH secretion can lead to Cushing's syndrome, characterized by:

  • Thin limbs due to muscle wasting and obese trunk due to fat redistribution.

  • Moon facies and buffalo hump can also be seen in Cushing's syndrome.

  • While paraneoplastic syndromes like SCLC are associated with various symptoms, the hallmark features of Cushing’s syndrome are especially relevant here, leading to the described pattern of thin limbs and obese trunk.

     
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 721.

questions.text: Which is the very first chemical barrier that microorganisms encounter for a commonly exposed body surface?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Acidic pH
 
  • First chemical barrier encountered by microorganism for common exposed surfaces of the body is acidic pH.
  • All surfaces of the body, which come in contact with the external environment, are equipped with mechanical and chemical barriers to prevent penetration by microorganisms.
  • Secretions of sebaceous glands contain both saturated and unsaturated fatty acids that kill bacteria and fungi.
  • The sebaceous secretions also have a low pH that inhibits bacterial growth.

  • Option 1: Lysozyme is an antimicrobial enzyme found in bodily fluids like tears, saliva, and mucus. While it plays an important role, it is not the first chemical barrier encountered on commonly exposed surfaces.

  • Option 3: Glycogen serves as a carbohydrate storage molecule and is not a direct antimicrobial barrier.

  • Option 4: Lactose is a sugar found in milk and does not act as a chemical barrier to microbes.

Online Reference: Janeway CA Jr, Travers P, Walport M, et al. Immunobiology: The Immune System in Health and Disease. 5th edition. New York: Garland Science; 2001. The front line of host defense. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK27105/

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of painful urination and hematuria. Urinalysis shows the presence of crystals. Which type of urinary crystal is most likely depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Struvite

The given image is of Struvite crystals (Coffin Lid shaped)
They are typically seen in UTI caused by urease-producing organisms (E.g. Proteus)

*[Extra Edge]:
  • Struvite stones, also known as infection stones or triple phosphate stones, form only when the upper urinary tract is infected with urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, or Providencia species.
  • Urease produced by these bacteria hydrolyzes urea and may elevate the urine pH to a supraphysiologic level (>8.0). Struvite stones may grow quickly and fill the renal pelvis (staghorn calculi).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2373.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes has been enrolled in a Phase 1 clinical trial for a new drug. What is the purpose of the Phase 1 clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug safety

Phase I: Human pharmacology and safety

The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects on vital functions, such as precipitous fall/rise in blood pressure or heart rate, arrhythmias, bronchospasm, seizures, kidney/liver damage, etc.
Unpleasant side effects are noted and an attempt is made to observe the pharmacodynamic effects in man. The human pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are measured for the first time.

Although Dosing, Pharmacodynamics is also being carried out in Phase 1 but most appropriate answer would be Drugs safety.


* Exam points about Drug development:




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 90.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and heart failure presents to your clinic for follow-up. His current treatment regimen includes thiazide diuretics. Which of the following is the site of action of Thiazide diuretics?
questions.solution:
• Thiazide diuretics primarily act on the Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT) of the nephron. They inhibit the Na+/Cl− cotransporter, which leads to a decrease in sodium and chloride reabsorption. This results in increased excretion of sodium, chloride, and water, which reduces blood volume and, consequently, lowers blood pressure. Thiazides are commonly used in the treatment of hypertension and heart failure due to their ability to decrease fluid overload and reduce vascular resistance.
  • Below is the image given below with detailed site of action of various diuretics




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 628-637.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a 10-year history of insulin-dependent diabetes presents with a new diagnosis of macular edema and glaucoma. Despite initial treatment, his condition remains difficult to manage, and you are considering the use of an additional medication to lower intraocular pressure. Which of the following drugs is the least appropriate choice for this patient with both macular edema and glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prostaglandin analogue
 
  • Prostaglandin analogues can potentially worsen diabetic macular edema and is generally not recommended in patients with diabetic retinopathy due to its potential effects on retinal fluid dynamics.
  • Therefore, it would be considered the least appropriate choice for managing glaucoma in this context. Common side effect of prostaglandin analogue is Cystoid Macular edema.

  • Option 1: Alpha agonists (e.g., brimonidine) can reduce aqueous humor production and have lesser negative impact on macular edema compared to prostaglandin analogues.

  • Option 3: Pilocarpine can be used to treat glaucoma in certain cases, although its use may be limited in certain conditions. It can cause pupil constriction and improve aqueous humor outflow, but it is not as likely to exacerbate macular edema.

  • Option 4: Beta blockers (e.g., timolol) also reduce aqueous humor production and are safe in patients with macular edema when used appropriately.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of joint pain and stiffness in both hands for the past 6 months. She reports that the stiffness is worst in the morning and lasts more than an hour. On examination, her metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are tender and swollen bilaterally. Laboratory studies reveal a positive rheumatoid factor and elevated ESR. The patient has recently been started on etanercept after poor response to methotrexate. What is the primary mechanism of action of etanercept in the treatment of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option1) Inhibition of TNF alpha
Etanercept is a biologic DMARD (Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drug) that acts as a decoy receptor for tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α). It binds TNF-α and prevents it from interacting with its natural receptors, thereby reducing inflammation and immune response in rheumatoid arthritis. It is particularly used when conventional DMARDs like methotrexate fail.
It is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1 and is administered by s.c injection 50 mg weekly. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.

TNF alpha inhibitors memorising trick:

Trick: -
ACE Inhibitor ko Goli maro
A-Adalimumab
C- Certolizumab
E- Eternacept
I-Infliximab
Goli- Golimumab

Various drugs used in management of Rheumatoid Arthritis


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 230.

questions.text: Which of the following is structurally complementary to the active site of an enzyme?
questions.solution:
The substrate is the specific molecule that binds to the active site of an enzyme. This binding is based on a "lock-and-key" or induced fit model, where the active site is complementary in shape and chemical environment to the substrate. This specificity is essential for enzyme activity.

  • The allosteric site is a separate site where regulatory molecules bind, influencing enzyme activity but not directly involved in substrate binding.

  • The product is the result of the enzymatic reaction, not complementary to the active site.

  • A reaction refers to the process, not a structural molecule.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No- 47.

choices.text: Decreased cardiovascular effects as compared to propofol

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is scheduled for a diagnostic upper endoscopy. As part of the procedural sedation, he receives midazolam intravenously. Which of the following is not caused by midazolam?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Retrograde amnesia 

Midazolam only causes Anterograde amnesia

 * Some important points
  • Water soluble
  • Rapid onset
  • Short acting
  • Anticonvulsant, Muscle relaxant
  • Anterograde amnesia (patient cannot form new memories after administration)
  • It does not cause retrograde amnesia—the inability to recall events that occurred before administration.
  • High margin of safety due to clinically inactive metabolites
  • Intranasal administration possible
  • Reversal agent – Flumazenil

  • Midazolam may show tachyphylaxis (decreased effect over time) with prolonged high-dose infusion.
    Compared to propofol, midazolam has less cardiovascular depression, making it safer in some patients with hemodynamic instability.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of valproate is gender-specific?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) polycystic ovarian syndrome

The most frequent side effects of valproate are "nausea (22%)" and "drowsiness (19%)."
Vomiting (12%), dizziness (12%), and weakness (10%)

* Severe side effects are:

  • Bleeding
  • reduced blood platelets
  • Encephalopathy
  • Suicidal actions and ideas
  • decreased body temperature

* Valproic acid may raise the risk of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) in females with epilepsy or bipolar disorder, according to some data.

Mechanism: 
- Increases androgen levels (via altered steroid metabolism in liver)
- Disrupts hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis
- May cause insulin resistance, contributing to PCOS pathology

Management

- Consider switching to another AED (like lamotrigine)
- Endocrine/gyn referral if symptoms persist
- Treat as per PCOS guidelines (e.g., OCPs, metformin)

MNEMONIC to remember adverse effects of Valproate: 
 

  • V – Vomiting (GI upset is a common early side effect)

  • A – Alopecia

  • L – Liver toxicity (hepatotoxicity, especially in young children)

  • P – Pancreatitis (can be life-threatening)

  • R – Reversible PCOS (unique to females, gender-specific side effect)

  • O – Obesity (weight gain is common with long-term use)

  • A – Ataxia (neurological symptoms like tremor and dizziness)

  • T – Teratogenicity (notably neural tube defects, so contraindicated in pregnancy)

  • E – Encephalopathy due to hyperammonemia



* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 444.

questions.text: Identify the drug that acts through intracellular receptors.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thyroxin

Only Thyroxine acts through intracellular receptors all other act via cell membrane receptors.

* [Extra Edge]:
  • Both T 3 and T4 penetrate cells by active transport and produce majority of their actions by combining with a nuclear thyroid hormone receptor (TR) which belongs to the steroid and retinoid superfamily of intracellular receptors.
  • Two TR isoform families (TRα and TRβ) have been identified. Both bind T 3 and function in similar manner, but their tissue distribution differs, which may account for quantitative differences in the sensitivity of different tissues to T3.
  • In contrast to the steroid receptor, the TR resides in the nucleus even in the unliganded inactive state. It is bound to the ‘thyroid hormone response element’ (TRE) in the enhancer region of the target genes along with corepressors


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 363.

choices.text: Probenecid given along with PnG decrease its duration of action

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Penicillin G?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Used for treatment rat bite fever
 
  • True statement about penicillin G is that it is used for treatment of rat bite fever.
  • Rat-bite fever is caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis (in the U.S.) or Spirillum minus (in Asia).
    → Penicillin G is the treatment of choice.
  • Leptospirosis or Rat Bite fever: PnG 1.5 MU injected i.v. 6hourly for 7 days is curative.
  • Penicillin being acid labile is not given by oral route. Its oral counterpart is Penicillin V, which is acid-stable.
  • It is not a broad-spectrum antibiotic. 
  • Penicillin G is narrow-spectrum, effective mainly against:
    → Gram-positive cocci (e.g. Streptococcus),
    → Anaerobes (e.g. Clostridium),
    → Some Gram-negative cocci (e.g. Neisseria).
  • DOC: Syphilis, rheumatic fever prophyla.xis, Streptobacillus moniliformis
  • Probenecid given along with penicillin G increase its action because it has affinity for tubular OATP, so it increases its efficiency by blocking the tubular transport of penicillin.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 768.

choices.text: Cefotaxime is more active against altered penicillin binding protein
Drug of choice is trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole but cannot be given

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents with complaints of high-grade fever, irritability, and refusal to eat for the past 2 days. On examination, he is febrile (39.4°C), irritable with a positive Brudzinski sign, and has neck stiffness. His fontanelle is bulging. Blood cultures and lumbar puncture are performed. Gram stain of the CSF reveals small, pleomorphic gram-negative coccobacilli, and CSF culture confirms Haemophilus influenzae type b. Why is cefotaxime chosen over ampicillin in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cefotaxime is more active against beta-lactamase
 
  • Cefotaxime or ceftazidime is the drug of choice for the treatment of Hemophilus meningitis.
  • Ampicillin and cotrimoxazole were popular for respiratory infections, but as plasmid-borne resistance to these drugs is now common, thus amoxicillin-clavulanate or clarithromycin is more effective, Plasmid for beta lactamase production makes them resistant.
  • Clinical tip: 

    In cases of bacterial meningitis, always assume the presence of resistant strains (like beta-lactamase producers) until sensitivity results are back. Hence, third-generation cephalosporins (like cefotaxime or ceftriaxone) are the empiric drugs of choice, especially in pediatric cases.

* [Extra Edge]:
Organism Drug of Choice
Streptococcus pneumoniae, s. viridians,
Hemolytic streptococci group A, B, C, G
Staphylococcus (non-penicillinase producing)
Actinomyces, Bacillus cereus, Clostridium
Neisseria meningitidis Treponema pallidum, T. pertenue		 Penicillin G
MRSA, Coagulase negative Staphylococcus

Enterococcus faecalis, Listeria Ampicillin
Bacillus anthracis
Borrelia burgdorferi, B. recurrentis
Chlamydia & Rickettsiae		 Doxycycline

Hemophilus ducreyi & Mycoplasma Azithromycin
Nocardia Cotrimoxazole
E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus

Serratia, Enterobacter, Acinetobacter Carbapenems
Bacteroides Metronidazole

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 777.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman undergoes a total abdominal hysterectomy for uterine fibroids. Her past medical history includes hypertension and controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. On postoperative day 1, the surgical team initiates thromboprophylaxis due to her risk factors and the nature of the surgery. Identify the correct route of administration for post operative thromboprophylaxis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) S/C
 
  • Postoperative patients, especially those undergoing major abdominal, pelvic, or orthopedic surgery, are at high risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Anticoagulant medications are used either for prophylaxis (prevention) or treatment of thrombosis.
  • Both LMWH and fondaparinux can be administered subcutaneously once per day for thrombosis prophylaxis and therapy, LMWH is the agent of choice in post operative thromboprophylaxis.
  • The SC route provides reliable absorption into the bloodstream, particularly for medications like LMWH and fondaparinux. Unlike IM injections (which may be erratic) or oral medications (which may have low bioavailability), SC injections offer predictable pharmacokinetics. 
  • Intramuscular injections are contraindicated in anticoagulated patients due to the risk of muscle hematoma. SC injections avoid this risk because they are given in loose connective tissue, where bleeding is much easier to control.
  • IV anticoagulation (like unfractionated heparin) requires hospital admission, continuous monitoring (aPTT), and infusion pumps. For routine prophylaxis, this is excessive and impractical.
  • Unfractionated heparin can be administered intravenously four times daily to treat thrombosis and subcutaneously twice daily for prevention.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 665.

questions.text: Cannabinoid oil is not indicated in_______
questions.solution:
• Cannabinoid oil is an oral deriative of the cannabis plant.
  • FDA has approved it use in treatment of seizures associated with
  1. Tuberous sclerosis,
  2. Dravet syndrome and
  3. Lennox Gastaut syndrome.
         It is not indicated in RETT syndrome.

  • Rett syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by MECP2 mutations.

  • While seizures are common, the role of cannabinoids is not well-established and not FDA-approved.

  • Management usually includes antiepileptic drugs, physical therapy, and supportive care.



Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
