She admits to taking “a handful of pills” the previous night after an argument. Vital signs are stable. On examination, she is drowsy but arousable. Laboratory results reveal elevated ALT/AST and mildly increased INR. NAPQI is an intermediate metabolite of which drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is 1. Paracetamol (also known as acetaminophen).
  • NAPQI (N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine) is a toxic metabolite that is formed during the metabolism of paracetamol (acetaminophen) in the liver. In therapeutic doses, paracetamol is primarily metabolized by conjugation with glucuronic acid and sulfate, which are nontoxic pathways.
  • However, when paracetamol is taken in excessive amounts or in the presence of certain risk factors, a significant portion of it is metabolized by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system in the liver, leading to the production of NAPQI.
  • NAPQI is highly reactive and can cause liver damage by depleting glutathione and forming toxic adducts with cellular proteins, causing centrilobular hepatic necrosis.
  • N-acetylcysteine (NAC) — replenishes glutathione, detoxifies NAPQI.
     

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 696 .

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is prescribed phenytoin and valproate after being diagnosed with epilepsy. She experienced a generalised rash all over her body four weeks later, which eventually went away after she stopped using both medications. When she is given another chance to take phenytoin and valproate, how many weeks will pass before the rash reappears?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 1 day
 
  • The situation given in the question appears to be of a hypersensitivity to Phenytoin.
  • Initial exposure to a drug allergen typically takes 1–4 weeks to develop a hypersensitivity reaction (like a rash).
  • Upon re-exposure, the immune system remembers the allergen, and the reaction can occur much more rapidly—often within 24 hours.
  • This is characteristic of Type IV hypersensitivity (T-cell mediated), commonly seen with phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine etc.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 419.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of nausea, constipation, fatigue, and confusion. He has a history of taking 60,000 IU of vitamin D daily for the past several months, thinking it would boost his bone health. Lab results reveal hypercalcemia, low PTH, and high serum 25(OH) vitamin D levels. What is the management in case of this person taking 60,000 IU of vitamin D for long time, which lead to Vitamin D toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2) Glucocorticoid

The use of glucocorticoid (Dexamethasone, prednisolone, etc.) therapy will lower plasma calcium levels by inhibiting the action of vitamin D (1,25D), which leads to decreased intestinal calcium absorption and increased urine calcium excretion. Loss of osteoid (decreased formation and increased resorption) indirectly results in loss of Ca2+ from bone, producing negative calcium balance.

Glucocorticoids are the treatment of choice because they:

  • Decrease intestinal calcium absorption

  • Reduce bone resorption

  • Lower 25(OH)D to 1,25(OH)2D conversion

  • Increase calciuresis (calcium excretion in urine)

Other medications like chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are less effective in treating hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity.
Use of bisphosphonates, calcitonin, loop diuretics with IV fluids, and in severe cases, dialysis can be done.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 309.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with long-standing hypertension and stage 4 chronic kidney disease (eGFR 18 mL/min/1.73m²) presents for evaluation of worsening blood pressure control. His serum potassium is borderline high, and he's already on furosemide. In renal failure, which of the following thiazide diuretics is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metolazone
 
  • Metolazone is a thiazide-like diuretic that retains its effectiveness even in patients with advanced renal failure, especially when used in combination with loop diuretics like furosemide. It acts at the distal convoluted tubule and helps mobilize fluid when other thiazides become ineffective due to low GFR.
  • Chlorthalidone, Chlorothiazide, and Methyclothiazide are less effective when GFR <30 mL/min.
  • Metolazone is often combined with loop diuretics for synergistic diuresis in volume-overloaded CKD patients.
  • Used to treat edema brought on by cardiac diseases (CHF), liver disease (hepatic cirrhosis), and kidney disease (nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis). 
  • When the GFR is less than 30–40 mL/min, metolazone and indapamide are beneficial.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 630.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with severe right eye pain, headache, and blurred vision that worsened after spending time in a dark theater. On examination, the eye is red with a mid-dilated pupil, shallow anterior chamber, and corneal haze. A prone dark room test triggers the pain. Intraocular pressure is elevated. Which medication from the list below has to be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Atropine
 
  • In the given case where a 36-year-old female on prone dark room test develops pain in the eyes. This is due to pupillary dilatation in the dark causing obliteration of the narrow angle in the anterior chamber. The most probable diagnosis is angle closure glaucoma.
  • Atropinic drugs are absolutely contraindicated in individuals with a narrow iridocorneal angle—may precipitate acute congestive glaucoma since it is a anticholinergic drug.
  • Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes pupillary dilation (mydriasis) and paralysis of accommodation (cycloplegia) — both of which worsen angle closure by increasing iris-lens contact and narrowing the anterior chamber angle.

Option 1 acetazolamide reduces aqueous formation by limiting generation of bicarbonate ion in the ciliary epithelium. It is used to supplement ocular hypotensive drugs for short-term indications like angle closure, before and after ocular surgery/laser therapy.

Option 2 and 4 pilocarpine and timolol have cholinergic/ parasympathomimetic action they penetrate cornea and promptly causes miosis, ciliary muscle contraction and fall in intraocular tension. Timolol is better than pilocarpine in cases of chronic dosing as the action is smooth and well sustained with lesser side effects like no induced myopia, no headache / brow pain and no fluctuation of intraocular pressure etc. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 132.

questions.text: A 49 year old male with history of alcohol consumption for many years developed liver cirrhosis. LFT of the patient shows GGT: 563 u/L, AST:180 u/L, ALT 150 u/L. Now he has stopped consumption. Which of the following is the most suitable drug to be given to avoid withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
• An alcoholic who has recently stopped consuming is at very high risk for withdrawal symptoms. The DOC for prevention/treatment of alcohol withdrawal is Benzodiazepines. However, in the above scenario - the patient also has features s/o CLD and cirrhosis, and most benzodiazepines being metabolized by the liver are contraindicated. 
  • Among the options provided, Lorazepam (option 1) would be the most suitable choice in this situation. Lorazepam is primarily metabolized in the liver, but it undergoes glucuronidation, which is a different metabolic pathway compared to other benzodiazepines that undergo oxidative metabolism. This means that lorazepam is less dependent on liver enzymes and may have a lower risk of accumulation in individuals with liver impairment. 
  • Diazepam, Clonazepam, and Alprazolam undergo hepatic oxidation, and their long half-lives can result in drug accumulation and oversedation in liver disease.


Benzodiazepines safe in hepatic failure 

Outside  - Oxazepam
The - Temazepam
Liver - Lorazepam
All of these undergo phase II conjugation (glucuronidation), which is preserved in liver dysfunction.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3561 .

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends after being found unresponsive at a party. According to his friends, he has a history of heroin abuse and they suspect he “used something again today.” On physical examination, the patient is unconscious, not responding to painful stimuli, respiratory rate is 9/min, oxygen saturation is 84%, heart rate is 58/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mmHg. On examination his pupil are pin point and react sluggishly to light. What will be the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IV naloxone
 
  • Heroine is diacetylmorphine. In case of opioid overdose IV Naloxone is used as treatment of choice.
  • Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that competitively binds to opioid receptors and reverses opioid-induced CNS and respiratory depression.
  • Naloxone is the drug of choice for morphine poisoning (0.4–0.8 mg i.v. every 2–3 min: max 10 mg) and for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid use during labor (10 µg/kg in the cord).
  • It is also used to treat overdose with other opioids and agonist-antagonists (except buprenorphine). Repeated doses of naloxone are needed because of its short duration of action.
Option 1: Oral naltrexone: Used for maintenance therapy after detoxification to prevent relapse. It is not useful in acute overdose due to delayed onset and oral route.
Option 3: Oral diazepam: A benzodiazepine, may worsen respiratory depression and is not an antidote for opioid overdose.
Option 4: IM buprenorphine: A partial opioid agonist, used for opioid maintenance therapy, not for overdose reversal.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is rushed to the emergency department with shortness of breath, generalized urticaria, and facial swelling 20 minutes after eating shrimp at a restaurant. She is hypotensive (BP: 78/50 mmHg), tachycardic (HR: 112 bpm), and has wheezing on auscultation. She is immediately diagnosed with anaphylaxis, and intramuscular epinephrine is administered. Which action of adrenaline is not noticed when treating anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Action on presynaptic alpha-receptors
 

Epinephrine (adrenaline) acts on multiple adrenergic receptors (α1, α2, β1, β2), and its effects are crucial in managing anaphylaxis. Here's how:

Relevant actions in ANAPHYLAXIS:

  • β2-receptors → Bronchodilation: Relieves bronchospasm.

  • β1-receptors → Increased heart rate & cardiac output: Counters hypotension and shock.

  • α1-receptors → Vasoconstriction: Increases BP and reduces mucosal edema in airway.


On the other hand, Presynaptic α2-receptors → These act as negative feedback regulators, reducing norepinephrine release. This does not contribute to the therapeutic effect in anaphylaxis and is not targeted during emergency treatment.

Clinical application: 

  • IM Epinephrine (0.3–0.5 mg in adults) is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis.

  • Administer into the anterolateral thigh for rapid absorption.

  • Repeat every 5–15 minutes if necessary.

  • Other adjuncts: Antihistamines, corticosteroids, fluids, bronchodilators (albuterol).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 145.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with new-onset generalized tonic-clonic seizures. MRI of the brain shows multiple cystic lesions in different stages. The radiology report mentions one lesion that appears hypodense with a hyperdense dot (scolex) and shows no surrounding edema.When does neurocysticercosis become non-edematous?
questions.solution:
There are four main stages of neurocysticercosis (also known as Escobar's pathological stages):

 1.Vesicular: viable parasite with intact membrane and therefore no host reaction. 

 2.Colloidal vesicular: parasite dies within 4-5 years untreated, or earlier with treatment and the cyst fluid becomes turbid.
As the membrane becomes leaky edema surrounds the cyst. This is the most symptomatic stage.

3.Granular nodular: edema decreases as the cyst retract further

4.Nodular calcified: end-stage quiescent calcified cyst remnant; no edema.

Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1493.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with fever for four days, followed by headache, neck stiffness, and erythematous rash on the chest. There was no prior travel or tick bite history. His CSF analysis revealed elevated protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis, and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Enterovirus
 

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with viral (aseptic) meningitis, and the most common viral cause is enterovirus, especially in young adults during summer/fall.

CSF clues supporting viral meningitis: 

  • Normal glucose

  • Elevated protein (mild to moderate)

  • Lymphocytic predominance

  • Few RBCs (may be incidental or due to traumatic tap)

    Other options: 

  • West Nile Virus: Often presents with flaccid paralysis or encephalitis in older/immunocompromised individuals; usually with travel/mosquito exposure.

  • S. pneumoniae: Causes bacterial meningitis → neutrophilic CSF, very high protein, low glucose.

  • N. meningitidis: Also bacterial; typically with petechial rash, neutrophilic CSF, low glucose, and high protein.




Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 677.

questions.text: Gas plasma sterilisers like STERRAD are employed in operating rooms to clean OT equipment. What one of the following is its active ingredient?
questions.solution:
• The Sterrad Sterilization System by Advanced Sterilization Products (ASP) exploits the synergism between peroxide and low-temperature gas plasma (an excited or ionized gas) to rapidly destroy microorganisms is a sterilization device that utilizes gas plasma to disinfect medical equipment in operation theaters.
  • Specifically, hydrogen peroxide is the active agent used in this device to eliminate hazardous microbes and pathogens that may be present. This technology can provide further safety and prevent any contamination while operating in the theater, enabling a safe and clean environment for all patients.
Commonly used methods of sterilisation :-


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 35.

questions.text: What is the name of the disease that this vector transmits?
questions.solution:
The image displayed is of a sandfly.
Primary vectors of Leishmaniasis are sandflies.

  • Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, which are transmitted to humans through the bite of infected female sandflies of the genus Phlebotomus (in the Old World) or Lutzomyia (in the New World).

  • Sandflies are small, hairy insects that are typically active during dusk and dawn. When they bite a person, they inject the Leishmania parasites, which then infect the host's skin and internal organs, leading to the disease.

The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is female sandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man. The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala azar.

Audio explanation for the above.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 55.

questions.text: Which among the following viral hemorrhagic fevers has occurred in India?
questions.solution:
Viral hemorrhagic fevers are zoonotic diseases brought on by viruses that live in arthropod vectors or animal reservoirs.

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (Option 3) has been reported in India.
It is caused by the Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever virus, a member of the Bunyaviridae family. This disease is transmitted by ticks and contact with infected animal blood and tissues.
Geographically, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is widely distributed. The first confirmed case of CCHF in India was noted in January 2011 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, during a nosocomial outbreak.

Option 1: Marburg virus, a Filovirus causing hemorrhagic fever, has not been reported in India.
Option 2: Although the Yellow fever virus, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, is common in parts of Africa and South America, India has not experienced recent outbreaks, although vaccination is recommended for travelers to endemic areas.
Option 4: The Ebola virus, which also causes hemorrhagic fever, has been a concern in African outbreaks but has not caused any indigenous cases in India, though there have been isolated cases among travelers.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 531.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with complaints of fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and pallor. He reports that he works as a farm laborer and frequently walks barefoot on the soil. On examination, you notice mild pallor. To which helminth does the egg seen in the following fecal examination belong?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ancylostoma duodenale

The eggs described in the fecal examination are characteristic of Ancylostoma duodenale, a hookworm. This helminth causes ancylostomiasis, often resulting in iron-deficiency anemia and fatigue due to blood loss from the intestinal mucosa. The patient's history of walking barefoot in areas with poor sanitation is typical for hookworm transmission, as larvae can penetrate the skin.

Features of the egg of Ancylostoma duodenale include oval in size, and space between ovum and eggshell. It contains 4-8 blastomeres which can be easily made out.

Other options:
Enterobius vermicularis- colourless, plano-convex, tadpole-shaped embryo.
Ascaris lumbricoides- Mostly round, golden brown colour with a large unsegmented ovum at the centre.
Trichuris trichura- Barrel-shaped with polar mucus plug at both ends.



Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the attachment effacement lesion depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
E.coli is a gram negative bacteria which is the most common facultative anaerobe present in human GIT.

Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC) is the correct answer. EPEC causes diarrhea, especially in infants, and is characterized by the attachment-effacement lesion, where the bacteria attach to the enterocyte membrane and cause effacement (loss) of the microvilli. This leads to watery diarrhea and sometimes fever and abdominal cramping. This attachment-effacement lesion is a hallmark of EPEC's pathogenesis, resulting from the formation of pedestals beneath the bacteria as they adhere to the intestinal epithelial cells.

Other options: 

  • Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) produces enterotoxins (heat-labile and heat-stable toxins) that lead to traveler's diarrhea or secretory diarrhea but does not cause the attachment-effacement lesion.

  • Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC) invades the intestinal epithelium, leading to inflammatory diarrhea similar to Shigella. It does not produce the characteristic attachment-effacement lesion.

  • Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC), notably O157:H7, causes bloody diarrhea and can lead to hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). EHEC's primary virulence factor is the Shiga toxin, which is not associated with the attachment-effacement lesion.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents to your clinic with concerns about avoiding toxoplasmosis during her pregnancy. She mentions that she cleans her cat's litter box regularly but is worried about the risk of infection. What is the infective stage of this organism in the cat feces?
questions.solution:
The infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii in cat feces is oocysts. These oocysts are excreted in the feces of cats after they ingest infected meat containing tissue cysts. Once in the environment, the oocysts sporulate (become infectious) after 1-5 days. Humans can become infected by ingesting the sporulated oocysts, typically through handling contaminated cat litter, soil, or unwashed vegetables.

In cats, the definitive hosts, both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur. The oocyst is formed through sexual reproduction, while tachyzoites and tissue cysts represent stages of asexual multiplication.

In intermediate hosts, such as humans, mice, and rats, only the asexual forms—tachyzoites and tissue cysts—are found.

Other options: 

  • Tissue cysts contain bradyzoites, which are the dormant form of the parasite that reside in tissues such as the brain, muscle, or eye of the host, but they are not the form shed in the cat's feces.

  • Tachyzoites are the rapidly dividing form of the parasite that are responsible for the acute infection phase, but they are not excreted in the cat's feces.

  • Bradyzoites are the slow-growing forms that reside in tissue cysts and are not present in the cat feces. They are the infective form to intermediate hosts like rodents and can also infect humans through the ingestion of tissue cysts from undercooked meat.


Reference : Paniker’s Textbook Of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page no 90-93 .

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of sneezing, runny nose, and itchy eyes. She reports that her symptoms tend to occur every spring when pollen levels are high. Physical examination reveals allergic rhinitis and conjunctivitis. Laboratory tests show increased serum IgE levels. Which of the following cell mediators are involved in the Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction?
i. Mast cell
ii. Histamine
iii. Prostaglandins
iv. Neutrophils
questions.solution:
In a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction (common in allergic conditions like allergic rhinitis), the following cell mediators are involved:

  • Mast cells (i) are the key effector cells that release histamine (ii) and prostaglandins (iii) upon activation by IgE antibodies, which lead to the symptoms of allergic rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, itching, runny nose). Mast cells are also responsible for the early-phase reaction in Type 1 hypersensitivity.

  • Histamine (ii) causes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, which results in the classic symptoms of allergic reactions, such as swelling, redness, and itching.

  • Prostaglandins (iii) contribute to inflammation and pain during an allergic response.

  • Neutrophils (iv) are more involved in Type 3 and Type 4 hypersensitivity reactions, not in Type 1 hypersensitivity.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 166.

choices.text: Most common mechanism is production of neutralizing substances
Plasmid mediated antibiotic resistance is always transmitted vertically
Complete elimination of the target is the mechanism of resistance to Vancomycin in some the strains of enterococcus
Alteration of target is the mechanism of resistance in some of the Pneumococcal strains

questions.text: With reference to antibiotic resistance, which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Plasmid mediated resistance is exclusively transmitted horizontally because the plasmid is not incorporated into the chromosome. This means that the plasmid must be shared between individuals through methods such as conjugation, transformation, or transduction in order to be transmitted from one individual to another.
Since all these are horizontal transmission mechanisms, it is implied that plasmid mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively by horizontal transfer. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: Which of the following features is incorrectly matched with the disease?
questions.solution:
• Immunodeficient individuals lack the normal response to antigens. Hence no reaction seen on contact with antigen. Example - False negative Mantoux test.
  • Chickenpox infection on microscopy shows cytopathic effect of formation of multinucleated giant cells, with rounding and ballooning of infected cells.
  • Berylliosis causes chronic granulomatous inflammatory and Biopsy reveals non-caseating granulomas with monocytic infiltration.  Non-caseating granulomas are the hallmark of berylliosis. These granulomas resemble those seen in sarcoidosis and do NOT show caseous necrosis, unlike tuberculosis.

Syphillis presents with the following lesions :

Primary syphilis - Hard chance, which is painless papule that becomes eroded and indurated.
Secondary Syphilis - Skin rashes on palms and soles which may be macular, papular, papulosquamous and nodular, but never vesicular or bullous.
Condylomata lata- mucocutaneous papules that coalesce to form large pink to grey lesions in warm moist intertriginous areas
Generalized lymphadenopathy is seen
Tertiary Syphilis - Gummas, which are locally destructive granulomatous lesions.

MNEMONIC for NO-CASEATING GRANULOMAS "Sarcoid BANGS"

S – Sarcoidosis
B – Berylliosis
A – Asbestosis (rarely granulomatous)
N – Non-tuberculous mycobacteria
G – Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s)
S – Systemic fungal infections (some, like histoplasmosis – early phase)



Reference: Essentials of Microbiology, 3rd edition, Page No 757 ,758.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate is brought to the outpatient department with fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, and tachypnea. On examination, the baby is alert but has signs of respiratory distress. A chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. There is no history of perinatal complications or NICU stay. Which infection is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given history is suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum (B/L Conjunctivitis) progressing to pneumonia. (Rapid breathing and infiltrates on chest X-Ray)

Neonatal Conjunctivitis is also known as ophthalmia neonatorum.
It can arise due to various causes (bacterial conjunctivitis, viral etc). Most common infectious cause is Chlamydia trachomatis infection. It usually occurs with 5 - 14 days of birth. Neonatal conjunctivitis + pneumonia with bilateral infiltrates strongly suggests Chlamydia trachomatis infection. 

Mnemonic to remember: "CHLAMYDIA"

  • C – Conjunctivitis

  • H – Hyperpnea (Tachypnea)

  • L – Low-grade or no fever

  • A – Atypical infiltrates

  • M – Mother-to-child transmission

  • Y – Young infant (2–8 weeks)

  • D – Dry staccato cough

  • I – Intracellular organism

  • A – Azithromycin responsive


Other options

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae - Rare in neonates, occurs in older children & adolescents. Hence, unlikely.
  • Haemophilus influenzae - Uncommon in newborns; usually causes epiglottitis, otitis media, or meningitis
  • Streptococcus - Can cause neonatal pneumonia but does not cause conjunctivitis

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 427.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old male with a history of kidney transplantation presents with persistent watery diarrhea, mild abdominal pain, and recent weight loss. He is immunosuppressed due to post-transplant therapy. The figure provides information on the worms' motility. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the organism?

a. Monoecious and the organism is related with parthenogenesis
b. Transmitted by intake of contaminated food and water
c. Loffler’s pneumonia is not caused by the same organism
d. Body gets this infection through filariform larvae
questions.solution:
The patient is likely infected with Strongyloides stercoralis, a helminth that can cause autoinfection, especially dangerous in immunocompromised individuals (such as transplant recipients). Key features:

  • Mode of infection: Skin penetration by filariform larvae (usually via barefoot walking on contaminated soil).

  • Diarrhea and malabsorption are common, but hyperinfection syndrome in immunosuppressed patients can lead to disseminated disease.

  • Löffler’s syndrome (transient pulmonary eosinophilia with cough and infiltrates) can occur, as larvae migrate through lungs.

  • The organism exhibits parthenogenesis in its life cycle (females reproduce without males), but it is dioecious, not monoecious.

 
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 181.

questions.text: Identify the conjugated antibody in the following figure:
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the antibody numbered 1 is the conjugate antibody.
 
The figure shows a molecular investigation technique which is used for the detection of the antibody marked 2. Since the antibody 1, is attached to the primary antibody (marked 2), it is known as the secondary or conjugated antibody with which a conjugated enzyme is attached. This conjugated enzyme is used to form an end product which can be easily detected. In this manner, the levels of Antibody 2 are measured indirectly.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue, joint pain, and a photosensitive rash over her cheeks. Her physician suspects systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and orders a test to detect antinuclear antibodies (ANA) in her serum. Which of the following techniques is used to detect Auto Antibodies?
questions.solution:
Indirect Immunofluoresence is used to detect antibodies against particular organisms.
This assay is used in detection of Auto antibodies in Auto immune disorders for eg. Anti nuclear Antibody {ANA} in SLE and in cases like syphlis for detection of micro-organisms like Trepenoma.

Other options: 

  • FISH – Used for chromosomal abnormalities, not autoantibodies.

  • Flow Cytometry – Useful for cell surface markers, immunophenotyping—not routinely for ANA.

  • ELISA – Can detect specific autoantibodies, but less sensitive for ANA than IIF; often used as a confirmatory or secondary test.

    Table showing comparison of different methods:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 182.

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer presents with complaints of progressive numbness and pain in both feet, followed by skin discoloration and ulceration. On examination, there is dry gangrene of the toes. He reports using well water for drinking for many years. Lab testing reveals elevated levels of a toxic metalloid. Which of the following metals is most likely responsible for his condition, also known as Blackfoot disease, an endemic peripheral vascular disease?
questions.solution:
Blackfoot disease results from chronic arsenic poisoning. In Taiwan, China, exposure to arsenic through drinking water has been linked to a severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD) that causes gangrene. This disease is characterized by platelet activation and increased blood coagulability in peripheral arteries and is commonly seen in regions with high arsenic levels.

Other options: 

  • Antimony – Toxic but primarily causes pneumoconiosis and irritation of mucous membranes.

  • Cadmium – Causes renal damage, Itai-Itai disease, and bone pain.

  • Barium – Associated with gastrointestinal and cardiac toxicity, not vascular gangrene.

    MNEMONIC FOR ARSENIC POISONING: "ARSENIC"

    A - Aldrich-Mees lines on nails
    R - Rain-drop pigmentation on skin, Red-velvety mucosal surfaces
    S - Subendocardial hemorrhage
    E - Excessive pigmentation & PVD - Blackfoot disease
    N - Neuritis
    I - Iron oxide + British-Anti Lewisite as treatment
    C - Cholera-like illnes

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 538-540,549 .

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after suspected industrial exposure to heavy metals. The toxicology team is preparing to start chelation therapy. Which chelating agent is not used in Heavy Metal Poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Pralidoxime (2-PAM) is not a chelating agent. It is used in organophosphate poisoning to reactivate acetylcholinesterase, not to chelate metals. It regenerates Active Acetylcholinesterase restoring Neuromuscular transmission.

  • BAL (Dimercaprol): Used for arsenic, lead (with EDTA), and mercury poisoning.

  • D-Penicillamine: Used for copper poisoning (e.g., Wilson’s disease) and sometimes lead and mercury.

  • EDTA (Calcium disodium EDTA): Used for lead poisoning, especially in children.

    Table showing common chelators, their uses & adverse effects: 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page. No: 123.

choices.text: If he is from a corporate hospital

questions.text: According to a recent Supreme Court ruling, a doctor can only be held accountable for medical negligence under Section 304-A in which of the following scenario:
questions.solution:
• Section 304-A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) pertains to culpable homicide not amounting to murder and covers cases of medical negligence resulting in death.
  • The Supreme Court has clarified that doctors can be held accountable for negligence under this section only if there is gross negligence—actions that go beyond a simple mistake or inadvertent error.
  • Physician can be held liable under Section 304-A if it is proven that a patient's death is due to the doctor's negligence, recklessness, or inattention, manifesting as a malicious intention or gross negligence.
  • Res Ipsa Loquitur refers to the legal principle where the mere occurrence of an event suggests negligence, but this is not the basis for accountability in Section 304-A.
  • Medical negligence under Section 304-A applies to any doctor regardless of the hospital setting (private, corporate, or government). The critical factor for determining negligence is the degree of negligence—specifically gross negligence—and not the nature of the hospital. Corporate hospitals do not have a special legal status in this context.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 290.

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
The image of burns with blisters and surrounding hyperemia suggests a diagnosis of antemortem burns.

In antemortem burns, a zone of hyperemia (a line of redness) is present at the edge of the burn area. This hyperemia, which varies in width, is due to tissue edema and capillary dilation, merging with the burn‘s edge. It affects the full thickness of the skin and persists even after death. If the entire body is burned, this line of redness will be absent.

Antemortem blisters appear as raised domes containing serous fluid with proteins and chlorides. The base of these blisters shows reddening and swollen papillae. In cases of antemortem burns, the skin adjacent to the burn area exhibits increased enzyme activity. This includes elevated levels of sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers, as well as increases in ATP esterases, aminopeptidases, and both acid and alkaline phosphatases. These changes, along with marked cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, are known as vital reactions and are characteristic of antemortem burns.

Other options: 
  • Barbiturate poisoning: Causes sedation and respiratory depression, but it doesn't typically cause burns with blisters.
  • Chemical burns usually present with edema, necrosis, and tissue destruction, not as blisters with redness and hyperemia.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune condition that causes blisters on mucosal surfaces and skin, but it does not cause the specific burn-like blistering seen in antemortem burns. It often starting in mucosal areas (like the mouth) and later on starts spreading to the skin.


 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 326,327,588,589 .

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who works in the dye industry arrives at the OPD with throat pain, vomiting, dark red feces, and conjunctivitis. Which of the following compounds is most likely responsible for this
questions.solution:
Based on the given history patient is most likely suffering from acute arsenic toxicity.
 

Arsenic exposure, especially in industrial settings like the dye industry, can cause symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress (vomiting, garlicky odor, dark red feces due to gastrointestinal bleeding), throat pain, and conjunctivitis. Arsenic poisoning is a known occupational hazard in dye industries, and it is associated with acute toxicity that can affect multiple organ systems, including the gastrointestinal and ocular systems. It mimics Cholera disease.

Other options:

  • Potassium permanganate: Exposure can cause skin and mucosal irritation but is less likely to cause dark red feces or the symptoms seen in this patient.

  • Lead sulphate: Lead poisoning presents with abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and a history of chronic exposure, not the acute symptoms described.

  • Thallium sulphate: Thallium poisoning typically causes neurological symptoms, hair loss, and gastrointestinal effects, but it is less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and dark red feces.



Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 538.

questions.text: Mr. X fired his rifle at Mr. Y, who moved and escaped with only a graze on his leg. There was only minor bleeding and no severe harm. Which part of the Indian Penal Code makes Mr. X subject for arrest?
questions.solution:
Because a dangerous weapon was used to voluntarily cause simple hurt in this instance, section 324 of the IPC applies.


Under Section 324 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means is punishable. In this case, Mr. X attempted to harm Mr. Y by firing a rifle at him, and Mr. Y sustained a graze wound with minor bleeding. The use of a rifle, which is a dangerous weapon, to cause harm falls under Section 324, which deals with causing hurt with a weapon (but not causing serious injury).

  • Section 302: Deals with murder (intentionally causing death), which does not apply here as Mr. Y survived.

  • Section 304: Deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder, applicable if death had occurred due to Mr. X's actions.

  • Section 326: Involves voluntarily causing grievous hurt with dangerous weapons, but since the injury was minor (a graze), it does not meet the criteria for grievous hurt.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 292.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He mentions that he recently worked with chemicals in a metal refinery where he was exposed to arsenic-containing compounds. Upon examination, he is diaphoretic, with mild confusion and tachycardia. His blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and his temperature is normal. A detailed history reveals that he also had dark-colored urine. The patient is suspected to be suffering from acute arsenic poisoning due to his occupational exposure. Treatment of acute arsenic poisoning is by?
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol > EDTA 


The treatment of acute arsenic poisoning involves the use of chelating agents, which bind with arsenic and aid in its elimination from the body. The commonly used chelating agents for arsenic poisoning are:

Dimercaprol (also known as British anti-lewisite or BAL): It is the first-line treatment for acute arsenic poisoning. Dimercaprol is administered by intramuscular injection and works by binding to arsenic and forming a complex that is excreted in the urine.

Calcium EDTA (ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid): It is an alternative treatment for arsenic poisoning, particularly in cases where the use of dimercaprol is contraindicated or unavailable. Calcium EDTA works by binding to arsenic and other heavy metals and promoting their excretion in the urine.

Dialyzed Iron: Not indicated for arsenic poisoning; used in iron overdose.

Desferoxamine: Used in iron toxicity, not arsenic.


Table showing key points in management of acute arsenic poisoning:

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 517,518,539,540,544,556,592 .

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after being sexually assaulted. The attending physician is considering collecting a vaginal swab for forensic examination. Within how many days a vaginal swab can be taken from a rape victim?
questions.solution:
Vaginal swab can be taken from a rape victim within 4 days.
 
  • Vaginal examination is done using a sterile speculum.
  • Examining the cervix, vaginal walls, and vault for redness, bruising, or tears. The case history, the amount of time that has passed since the assault and the examination, the type of assault, and whether or not she has showered or washed herself since the assault all influence the type of swabs and samples that are taken.
  • The likelihood of obtaining evidence is considerably diminished after 72 hours (3 days),but can be taken up to 96 hours (4 days).
  • After 96 hours, evidence from the outside of the body and from objects like clothing can be gathered.
Extra edge: 

The SAFE kit (Sexual Assault Forensic Evidence kit) is a specialized set of tools and supplies used to collect and preserve evidence from a sexual assault victim. This kit is designed to gather forensic evidence while ensuring the victim’s privacy, safety, and dignity during the process.

Key Components of the SAFE Kit:

  1. Swabs: Used for collecting biological samples such as semen, blood, or saliva.

  2. Vaginal and Rectal Swabs: To collect evidence of sexual assault.

  3. Combs: To collect pubic hair or other bodily hair evidence.

  4. Photographic Documentation: To capture injuries or other evidence.

  5. Urine Sample Collection Kit: To test for drugs or alcohol in cases of suspected drug-facilitated sexual assault.

  6. Clothing Evidence Bags: To securely store clothing worn by the victim that might contain evidence such as bodily fluids or hairs.

  7. DNA Evidence Collection: Special kits and containers designed to preserve DNA evidence for later testing.

  8. Instructions: Detailed instructions on how to properly collect and preserve evidence.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 365.

questions.text:
A police officer brings a female skull to the forensics division for examination.
Which of the following characteristics would this skull bone need to have in order to be considered female?
(i) Prominent frontal and parietal eminence.
(ii) Narrow mastoid
(iii) Small and smooth glabella
(iv) Square orbits
(v) Prominent cheek
(vi) Round forehead
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. (i), (ii), (iii), (vi)
 

  • Prominent frontal and parietal eminence (i): In females, the frontal and parietal regions of the skull tend to be more rounded and prominent, giving the forehead a smoother and more rounded appearance.

  • Narrow mastoid (ii): The mastoid process in females is generally smaller and more narrow compared to males, where it is larger and more robust.

  • Small and smooth glabella (iii): The glabella, the smooth area between the eyebrows, is less pronounced and smoother in females, while it is often more pronounced and angular in males.

  • Round forehead (vi): A female skull typically has a more vertical and rounded forehead, unlike the sloping forehead seen in male skulls.



* Differences in male and female skull: 





Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 60.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was involved in a road traffic accident. He was struck by a vehicle while crossing the street and was immediately taken to the emergency department. Which of the following type of injury is unlikely after Road Traffic Accident?
questions.solution:
In a road traffic accident (RTA), common injuries include:

  • Contusions (bruises): These are typically caused by blunt force trauma, which is common in RTAs.

  • Lacerations: These are tears or cuts in the skin caused by impact with sharp objects or surfaces, which can easily occur during a crash.

  • Abrasions: These are superficial injuries where the skin is scraped off, often from contact with rough surfaces like the road or vehicle, which is very common in RTAs.

Chop wounds (option 1), however, are a type of injury typically caused by a heavy, sharp object like an axe or a similar weapon, and are unlikely to occur in a road traffic accident. Therefore, chop wounds are not commonly seen in these types of accidents.



Reference: Simpson's Forensic Medicine, Page No: 88, 90.

questions.text: Identify the mechanical injury shown in the picture.
questions.solution:
• Hesitation wounds, also known as hesitation marks, are shallow cuts or scratches that are often seen in cases of self-harm or attempted suicide. Hesitation wounds are so named because they are thought to be the result of hesitation or uncertainty on the part of the individual, who may be unsure about whether or not they want to carry out their suicidal or self-harming impulses.
  • They are superficial cuts or scratches on the skin that are typically smaller and less severe than the final self-inflicted wound. They are often irregular in shape and may appear shallow or jagged. Hesitation wounds are usually located near the intended site of the final wound, such as on the wrists or arms, and may be seen as an indicator of hesitation or ambivalence on the part of the individual. These cuts are typically shallow, irregular, and located in areas such as the wrists, forearms, or other accessible body parts.
Other options: 

  • Grazed abrasion: Superficial skin scraping caused by friction with a rough surface, not a cut.

  • Sixpenny bruises: Small, circular bruises from repeated blunt force trauma, often caused by a specific object like a hammer.

  • Patterned abrasion: Skin abrasion that shows a distinct pattern, usually from contact with an object with a specific shape or texture.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 181,185,189,194 .

questions.text: Identify the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Marbling

The given image shows Marbling.
Marbling of Skin refers to the mosaic like pattern on the skin which is seen at vein coverage due to production of H2S gas by the bacteria which combines with Hb present in the blood to form a greenish blue compound called Sulf-met-hemoglobin. It is usually seen ~ 36 hours since death.

Other options: 

  • Filagree burns: These are patterns that resemble lace-like or feathery designs, typically caused by specific heat or flame exposures on the skin.

  • PMS (Post-mortem Staining): Refers to the discoloration of the skin after death due to the settling of blood in dependent parts of the body.

  • Algor Mortis: Refers to the cooling of the body after death, not to any discoloration or marbling of the skin.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 166.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the orthopedic clinic with a 2-month history of gradually increasing pain in the left knee. The pain is localized to the proximal tibia, and the child has difficulty walking and playing. The child’s parents report no history of trauma. On examination, there is mild tenderness over the proximal tibia, with no visible deformities or swelling. A radiograph is performed, which reveals a symmetric, expansile, lytic lesion in the proximal tibia. All of the following treatments can be given to a 4-year old  with a symmetric, expansile lytic lesion in the proximal tibia except:
questions.solution:
All of the following can be done for his treatment except radiotherapy.

Features are suggestive of a solitary bone cyst.

Treatment of solitary bone cysts of the gnathic bones is surgical. Curettage of the boney walls, and often the biopsy procedure itself, will incite healing.

Radiotherapy: This is typically not used for benign bone lesions in children. It is reserved for malignant bone tumors or in rare cases of benign aggressive lesions that do not respond to other treatments. Radiotherapy in children should be avoided due to its potential long-term side effects, such as growth disturbances and an increased risk of secondary malignancies.

Other options: 

  • Curettage: Removal of the lesion by scraping; commonly used for benign bone lesions like unicameral bone cysts or fibrous dysplasia.

  • Intralesional steroids: Steroid injections used to shrink unicameral bone cysts and prevent recurrence, reducing the need for surgery.

  • Intralesional sclerosing agents: Injecting substances like alcohol to close lesions, commonly used for aneurysmal bone cysts.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 249

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a complaint of knee pain for the past 6 months. His symptoms have been progressively worsening, and he has difficulty with mobility. X-ray is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• X-ray shows a circumscribed osteolytic bone tumour involving the epiphysis - the most likely diagnosis is Giant cell tumor.
  • Giant cell tumor is a benign bone tumor that typically affects young adults between the ages of 20 and 40 years old.
  • It is more common in women than in men and frequently occurs in the long bones, such as the femur or tibia.
  • GCT typically involves the epiphysis of long bones (such as the femur, tibia, and distal radius) and is characterized by an osteolytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance on X-ray.
Other options
  • Multiple myeloma- commonly seen in older age group atleast around 60 years of age. Affects bones including the spine, ribs, pelvis, and skull. Multiple lytic lesions, also called "punched-out" lesions.
  • Simple bone cyst will be a well defined radiolucent lesion commonly seen in bones of upper limb and in an age group of 10-20. It is characterized by a fluid-filled cavity within the bone. No aggressive features like cortical destruction or soft tissue mass.
  • Adamantinoma is a rare low-grade malignant bone tumor typically found in the diaphyses of long bones in 20-40 year olds. Lytic lesion with a well-defined border, but may also show areas of sclerosis (mixed appearance). Cortical destruction and permeative bone pattern are common.
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 237,238

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents because of persistent leg pain that has been ongoing for the past 3 months. The pain is worse at night and often wakes him from sleep. He reports significant relief after taking ibuprofen. There is no history of trauma or fever. On physical examination, the child is afebrile with localized tenderness over the midshaft of the tibia, but no swelling or redness is observed. A lytic lesion with sclerotic borders was visible on the X-ray. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Osteoid osteomas are benign bone-forming tumors that typically occur in children (particularly adolescents).
  • They have a characteristic lucent nidus <1.5 or 2 cm and surrounding osteosclerotic reaction, which classically causes night pain that is relieved by the use of NSAIDs.
       

Osteoid osteoma X-ray image
  • Fibrous cortical defect is another benign lesion that can present with a lytic lesion on X-ray, but it does not have the characteristic sclerotic border seen in osteoid osteoma.
  • Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that usually presents with pain and a soft tissue mass.
  • Fibrous dysplasia is a benign bone lesion that can present with a ground-glass appearance on X-ray, but it does not have the characteristic lytic lesion with sclerotic borders seen in osteoid osteoma.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 235,236

questions.text: Uses for a counterforce brace include:
questions.solution:
Counter force brace is used in tennis elbow.
  • Counterforce braces help keep pressure off of the inflamed muscles by spreading tension to different parts of arm.
  • Instead of continually stressing the same forearm muscles and tendons when making certain movements, wearing a counterforce brace allows them to rest by re-distributing this pressure.

  • Indications: Lateral epicondylitis (Tennis elbow): Disperses stress away from the tendon origin at the lateral epicondyle (extensor carpi radialis brevis).
    Sometimes medial epicondylitis (Golfer’s elbow)

    Below is image of counterforce brace

   
Other options: 
Foot drop is managed using an Ankle-Foot Orthosis (AFO), which helps keep the foot in a dorsiflexed position during walking to prevent tripping.
Ankle sprains are treated with ankle braces or taping, which provide support and limit excessive movement to promote healing.
Wrist drop, often due to radial nerve palsy, is managed with a cock-up splint or wrist extension orthosis to maintain wrist position and function.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 302

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with a history of dull, persistent pain in the upper arm, low-grade fever, and mild swelling over the past several weeks. On examination, he has mild tenderness over the proximal humerus with no erythema or significant warmth. He denies trauma. X-ray is shown below. What pathology is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
In this X-ray of the humerus head, we can see a faint patch loss of density and a sequestrum within the bone. This along with the young age, is suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.
 

  • Chronic osteomyelitis typically presents with long-standing localized pain, sometimes with draining sinuses. Imaging shows sequestrum (necrotic bone), involucrum (new bone formation), and patchy osteolysis.

  • Ewing’s sarcoma presents with onion-skin periosteal reaction and systemic signs like fever, commonly in diaphysis of long bones.

  • Osteosarcoma shows sunburst appearance or Codman triangle, typically around the metaphysis of long bones.

  • Acute osteomyelitis has more acute presentation with high fever, pain, and systemic toxicity; radiographic changes are often minimal early on.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 172

questions.text: Who among the following has contributed to the development of neuro-otology and is considered as the father of 'neuro-otology'?
questions.solution:
William F. House considered as 'Father of Neuro-otology' because of his pioneering development approaches for the removal of acoustic tumors and the management of patients with disabling vertigo.

  • He developed the translabyrinthine and middle fossa approaches to access tumors such as vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas).

  • He played a key role in advancing cochlear implant technology.

  • His work laid the foundation for modern neuro-otologic surgery, a subspecialty combining aspects of neurology, neurosurgery, and otology.

       
    DR. WILLIAM F. HOUSE: Inventor of Cochlear Implant

Reference:https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&url=https%3A%2F%2Fjamanetwork.com%2Fjournals%2Fjamaotolaryngology%2Ffullarticle%2F1655075&psig=AOvVaw183fftXAqgVpwwo0tz88mX&ust=1725450852512000&source=images&cd=vfe&opi=89978449&ved=0CAYQrpoMahcKEwjolO2p26aIAxUAAAAAHQAAAAAQBA

questions.text: A 58-year-old right-handed man is brought to the clinic by his daughter due to difficulty with speech. He struggles significantly to repeat phrases and has difficulty naming common objects. However, comprehension, fluency, and understanding of written language are unchanged. He's presumably suffering from?
questions.solution:
• Conduction aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus.
  • The connection between the Wernicke's (language comprehension) and Broca's (Language production) areas is lost.
  • The hallmark of conduction aphasia is the inability to repeat words. Comprehension and the expression of language are intact but patients cannot transfer the understood word to Broca's area to be expressed.
  • Conduction aphasia results in meaningful fluent speech and relatively good comprehension but very poor repetition.
Other options: 

  • Anomic aphasia: Difficulty in naming objects but repetition and comprehension are preserved.

  • Broca’s aphasia: Non-fluent, effortful speech with impaired repetition and naming, but comprehension is preserved.

  • Transcortical sensory aphasia: Fluent speech and intact repetition, but poor comprehension and impaired naming.

 





Different types of aphasia & their anatomic correlation

Reference : HARRISON'S Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition - pg.196 table 30.1

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She weighs 55 kg and has no history of difficult airway or cardiopulmonary disease. The anesthesiologist plans to use a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) for airway management during the procedure.What is the appropriate LMA size for an average adult patient weighing 55 kg?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device designed to sit in the hypopharynx and cover the glottis. It allows for ventilation without entering the trachea, making it a valuable tool in both elective and emergency airway management.

LMA sizing is primarily based on the patient’s body weight. 
According to the weight of 55 kgs, the size used should be 4.





Reference: Tetsuro Kagawa, Hidefumi Obara; An Easy Formula to Remember the Laryngeal Mask Airway Size–Patient Weight Relationship. Anesthesiology 2000; 92:631 doi: https://doi.org/10.1097/00000542-200002000-00063
Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1389.

choices.text: Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
Insert a cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with a history of severe, persistent upper gastrointestinal bleeding for the past 2 hours. He has vomited large amounts of bright red blood. He is awake and hemodynamically stable, though he appears anxious and is coughing intermittently during the evaluation. What will the first management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
  • In any case of massive upper GI bleeding, the first priority is airway protection, even when the patient is awake and stable. Hematemesis increases the risk of aspiration, especially with ongoing vomiting and blood in the oropharynx. Placing the patient in the recovery (lateral) position helps protect the airway while preventing aspiration.
  • The airway is the most crucial system at risk in this patient and needs prompt care because the patient's hemodynamics are stable.
  • To reduce the danger of aspiration of blood, the patient should be placed in a recovery posture, or left lateral decubitus.

Option 1: Do an urgent upper GI endoscopy
This is important for diagnosing and treating the source of bleeding but is not the immediate priority when the patient is hemodynamically stable and awake.
Option 3: Insert a cannula and start IV fluids
Fluid resuscitation is important, but airway protection should be prioritized before starting IV fluids in a patient with severe hemorrhage.
Option 4: Send for blood transfusion
Blood transfusion is crucial for severe blood loss, but it’s not the immediate step when the patient is stable, and airway management should come first.

Management of Hematemesis:


 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 391, 392.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of alcohol consumption since the age of 20 presents to the clinic. He reports that he currently drinks 3 quarters of alcohol daily and has been doing so for the past 30 years. However, recently, he finds that he experiences the same "kick" after drinking only a quarter of alcohol. He denies any other new symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Reverse tolerance.
  • When a heavy drinker develops liver damage, the liver no longer generates as much of the enzymes required to break down alcohol in the body as it once did, resulting in reverse tolerance.
  • Reverse tolerance occurs when the body becomes more sensitive to the effects of a drug over time, even with lower doses.
Other options:
  • Mellanby effect is the idea that people experience more intense alcohol intoxication symptoms when their blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is increasing than when it's decreasing even if the BAC is same in both cases.
  • Withdrawal: This occurs when a person reduces or stops alcohol consumption after prolonged heavy drinking, leading to symptoms such as tremors, anxiety, nausea, and sweating. It is not related to a reduced amount of alcohol producing the same effect, as seen in the case described.
  • Cross tolerance: This occurs when tolerance to one substance (e.g., alcohol) results in tolerance to a different but pharmacologically similar substance (e.g., benzodiazepines). It is not applicable in the current situation, where the individual’s tolerance to alcohol itself is decreasing.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 617

choices.text: Recall of events and avoidance of trauma

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who was involved in a road traffic accident (RTA) is diagnosed with PTSD. What distinguishes PTSD from all other disorders?
questions.solution:
The distinguishing feature of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) from other disorders is:

1. Recall of events and avoidance of trauma.

This is because re-experiencing the traumatic event (through intrusive memories, flashbacks, or nightmares) and avoidance (avoiding reminders of the trauma, such as places, people, or activities that may trigger memories of the event) are hallmark symptoms of PTSD. These symptoms are unique to PTSD and distinguish it from other mental health disorders.

Here’s why the other options aren’t as distinguishing:

  • Option 2 (Nightmares about events): While nightmares are a common symptom of PTSD, they are not exclusive to this disorder. Other anxiety or trauma-related disorders can also involve nightmares.
  • Option 3 (Autonomic arousal and anxiety): Increased arousal and anxiety can occur in several disorders, including generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and others.
  • Option 4 (Depression): Depression is a symptom that can be present in various disorders, not just PTSD.

The re-experiencing and avoidance elements are what most clearly define PTSD as a unique disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 440-442.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of alcohol dependence syndrome is admitted to the hospital by his wife. He has been consuming 120 ml of alcohol daily for the past 12 years. On admission, he reports having had alcohol earlier in the morning. Which medication/therapy from the list below needs to be avoided?
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 2:  DISULFIRAM
  • Disulfiram inhibits the acetaldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme thereby increasing the level of acetaldehyde in the body which causes various unpleasant symptoms like nausea hepatotoxicity etc.
  • Disulfiram is used to condition the patient to abstain from alcohol use. It should not be given until the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12-24 hours. A person taking Disulfiram drug should not take alcohol during the treatment as well as 14 days after stopping the drug.
     
Other options: 
 
  • Ondansetron: Used in the treatment of nausea and vomiting, particularly in patients undergoing chemotherapy. It does not interact with alcohol, and can be used in this patient.
  • Naltrexone  is  used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol. It is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be used as a part of the treatment plan.
  • Acamprosate  is  used to reduce the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal and prevent relapse in alcohol dependence. It is not contraindicated in this scenario and can be used as a part of the treatment plan.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 638, 639.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of nightmares, flashbacks, and anxiety after being involved in a traumatic car accident 6 months ago. He has been avoiding reminders of the incident and is experiencing difficulty sleeping and concentrating. He is seeking treatment for her symptoms, which are consistent with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Which of the following approaches to treating post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is the most effective?
questions.solution:
• Both Trauma focussed Cognitive behavioral therapy and Eye movement desensitization and reprocessing have been shown to be efficacious for therapy for the treatment of PTSD.
  • Most meta-analysis/systematic reviews have shown them to have equal efficacy. 
  • The Better answer however would be option (1). CBT is more accessible, and more widely used and the component of eye movement in EMDR has been questioned. It involves helping the patient confront and process the trauma in a controlled and safe environment, addressing negative thoughts and behaviors associated with the traumatic event.

Other Options:

  • Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing (EMDR) (Option 2) is also an effective treatment for PTSD. It involves processing distressing memories with bilateral stimulation (e.g., eye movements), but CBT is still generally considered the first-line treatment for PTSD due to its extensive evidence base.

  • Hypnosis (Option 3) has limited evidence supporting its effectiveness for PTSD and is not considered a first-line treatment.

  • Rational and Emotive Therapy (Option 4) is a form of cognitive therapy that targets irrational beliefs but is not specifically designed for PTSD, and it lacks the targeted approach of trauma-focused CBT.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 438, 445.

questions.text: A 45 year-old male presents with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base along the T3 dermatome on the trunk. Which of the following etiological agent is most likely to be implicated?
questions.solution:
• Varicella zoster or shingles is a condition characterized by painful, unilateral vesicular eruptions that occur in a single dermatome, usually on the T3 to L3 area, caused by Varicella Zoster virus (Option 1).
  • The word "shingles" comes from the Latin word "cingulum", meaning "belt" or "girdle", referring to the way the rash typically appears in a band-like or girdle-shaped pattern around one side of the body, often in a specific dermatome.
  • The prodromal phase of segmental pain preceding the eruption typically starts 1-4 days before its appearance.
  • Edema and erythema are quickly followed by the tuft of vesicles. In some cases, the mucous membranes within the dermatome may also be involved.
Other options: '

  • Herpes simplex (Option 2) causes painful blisters, but it more commonly appears around the mouth (herpes labialis) or genital areas (genital herpes), not in a dermatomal distribution like shingles.

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option 3) causes warts and not painful, blister-like lesions in a dermatomal pattern.

  • Pox virus (Option 4) refers to the family of viruses, such as variola (smallpox), but it does not cause the characteristic vesicular rash seen in shingles.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.27

questions.text:
As shown in the picture, a young boy with greasy skin exhibits acne.
What is the proper course of treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
• The diagram shows severe nodulocystic acne with pus filled lesions.

  • Nodulocystic acne is a severe form of acne involving deep, inflamed nodules and cysts, often painful and associated with scarring.

  • Oral isotretinoin is the treatment of choice in this case. It:

    • Drastically reduces sebaceous gland size and sebum production.

    • Normalizes follicular keratinization.

    • Has powerful anti-inflammatory properties.

    • Is typically given for 4–6 months and requires close monitoring due to potential side effects (e.g., teratogenicity, hepatotoxicity, mood changes).

Other options: 

  • Topical retinoic acid: Only effective in mild to moderate acne.

  • Benzoyl peroxide: Good for comedonal or papulopustular acne, not severe cystic types.

  • Oral steroids: Not used for acne unless there's an associated condition (e.g., acne fulminans).





Mechanism of action of anti-acne drugs: 



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37

questions.text: The figure depicts a 65-year-old man who has tense blisters and itching on otherwise normal-appearing skin with urticarial plaques. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• A 65-year-old patient with tense blisters on urticated (itchy, hive-like) skin is classic for bullous pemphigoid, which is a chronic autoimmune blistering skin condition affecting elderly patients.
  • Bullous pemphigoid is an subepidermal immunobullous disorder that affects older age groups leading to blisters/ bullae on urticated as well as normal looking skin and associated pruritus.
  • Antibodies are formed against hemidesmosomal proteins [ BP antigen 230 (BPAG1) & BP antigen 180 (BPAG2 Or Type XVII Collagen)]
  • These antibodies cause damage to dermo-epidermal junction leading to a sub-epidermal split in the skin.
Other options:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris: Flaccid blisters, painful erosions on mucosa and skin, +Nikolsky sign, affects middle-aged people.

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis: Intensely pruritic grouped vesicles, extensor surfaces, associated with celiac disease, seen in younger adults.

  • IgA pemphigus: Rare, resembles pemphigus foliaceus, intraepidermal blisters, IgA deposition, not typically urticarial.

    Table showing co,parison of different dermatoses:




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.10

questions.text: The following histological picture of a patient's skin sample suggests:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • The image shows the suprabasal acantholysis seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune skin disorder with IgG antibodies against desmoglein (a component of desmosomes, which connect keratinocytes in the stratum spinosum).
  • Flaccid intraepidermal bullae can be caused by acantholysis (separation of keratinocytes, resembling a “row of tombstones”).
  • It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Immunofluorescence reveals antibodies around epidermal cells in a reticular (fishnet-like) pattern
  • Nikolsky sign will be positive. (separation of epidermis upon manual stroking of skin).

Other options: 

  • Leprosy: Granulomatous inflammation involving peripheral nerves and skin. Shows non-caseating granulomas, not acantholysis.

  • Lichen Planus: Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction with sawtooth pattern of rete ridges.

  • Psoriasis: Shows parakeratosis, Munro microabscesses, elongated rete ridges, and regular acanthosis, but no acantholysis.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.6

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with burns sustained after accidentally spilling hot tea on his forearm. On examination, the area appears red, very painful, moist, and blistered. The blisters are intact and the capillary refill is brisk. Sensation to light touch is preserved. In a superficial partial-thickness burn, which layer is involved in blister formation?
questions.solution:
The American Burn Association (ABA) has published an educational resource that reviewed the classification and management of the burn wound. The classification system below is largely in agreement.
  • Superficial Burns
A superficial (first-degree) burn involves the epidermis only. These burns can be pink-to-red, without blistering, are dry, and can be moderately painful. Superficial burns heal without scarring within 5 to 10 days.
 
  • Partial-Thickness Burns

A second-degree burn, also known as a superficial partial-thickness burn, affects the superficial layer of the dermis (Papillary dermis). Blisters are common and may still be intact when first evaluated. Once the blister is unroofed, the underlying wound bed is homogeneously red or pink and will blanch with pressure. These burns are painful. Healing typically occurs within 2 to 3 weeks with minimal scarring.

A deep partial-thickness burn involves the deeper reticular dermis, can also present with intact blisters. Once the blisters are debrided, the underlying wound bed is mottled and will sluggishly blanch with pressure. The patient with a partial-thickness burn experiences minimal pain, which may only be present with deep pressure. These burns can heal without surgery, but it takes longer, and scarring is unavoidable.
 
  • Full-Thickness Burns

A third-degree burn, also known as a full-thickness burn, is most severe and affects the epidermis and dermis skin layers. They also extend into the subcutaneous tissue. These burns result in a leathery, stiff, and dry appearance. At this depth, the affected area does not blanch under pressure due to compromised blood supply. The nerves at this depth are also damaged, resulting in the patient experiencing no sensation or pain. These burns take more than 8 weeks to heal and require surgical treatment.





Reference- Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no 669

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl has a slow onset soft, uncomfortable swelling on the back of her leg. Without any significant arterial feeder, colour Doppler revealed several venous channels. Except for________, all of the following are employed as liquid embolizing agents
questions.solution:
Except for absolute alcohol, all of the other options (polyvinyl alcohol, sodium tetradecyl sulfate, and cyanoacrylate) are employed as liquid embolizing agents for treating venous malformations or varices.
Absolute alcohol is used as a sclerosing agent rather than a liquid embolic agent in such cases.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 228.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a head injury following a road traffic accident, and on examination, he is noted to have an open femur shaft fracture. The patient is conscious but has complaints of dizziness and confusion. What should be done first in the management of a head injury case with an open femur shaft fracture?
questions.solution:
The ABCs of trauma assessment-airway, breathing/oxygenation and circulation-represent the first steps in determining the extent of injury and patient care priorities.

In trauma, particularly when head injury is suspected alongside a fracture, the most critical step is ensuring airway protection and stabilizing the patient’s vital functions. Here’s why intubation should be prioritized:

  • Intubation is necessary to secure the airway and prevent respiratory compromise. The patient is conscious, but the presence of dizziness, confusion, and a potential head injury (such as concussion, contusion, or bleeding) poses a risk for rapid deterioration in the level of consciousness.

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) should be monitored to assess neurological status, and if the GCS is less than 8, intubation is indicated. Even with a conscious patient, there is a risk of deterioration, and airway protection should be established before proceeding with other treatments.

  • The head injury might worsen, leading to an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP), which can affect respiratory drive and protective reflexes, making intubation a priority.

  • Intubation will also allow for controlled ventilation if needed and the administration of oxygen to ensure adequate oxygenation.

In the question patients GCS has not been mentioned. If less than 9, patient should be intubated.
Better answer for option 3 instead of intubation would be assessment of Airway and protection.

Other Options:

Neurosurgery consultation (Option 1): While a neurosurgery consultation is essential for evaluating the head injury and potential complications, it is not the first step. Airway protection takes priority over consultation.

Give IV fluids (Option 2): IV fluids are important for fluid resuscitation if hypovolemia or shock is suspected, but they should only be administered after securing the airway to avoid complications from impaired respiratory function.

Splintage of fracture (Option 4): Fracture stabilization is necessary but should be done after airway management to ensure that the patient’s breathing and oxygenation are maintained first.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 364.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the ED after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is alert but complains of abdominal discomfort. The trauma team performs a quick sonogram abbreviated as FAST. Full form of FAST is:
questions.solution:
Full form of FAST is focused assessment by sonogram in trauma.
 

FAST stands for Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma. It is a rapid bedside ultrasound used in trauma settings to detect free fluid in the peritoneal cavity (such as in the hepatorenal pouch, splenorenal pouch, pelvis) and pericardial space. It is most helpful in blunt abdominal trauma to quickly identify internal bleeding or cardiac tamponade.

eFAST or Extended FAST includes all the areas assessed in FAST plus additional views to evaluate for pneumothorax and hemothorax in the thoracic cavity. It adds ultrasound assessment of the anterior chest wall to detect absence of lung sliding (pneumothorax) and the posterolateral chest to detect pleural fluid (hemothorax).

So, while FAST checks for intra-abdominal and pericardial fluid, eFAST extends this to include the chest, making it valuable in both blunt and penetrating thoracoabdominal trauma.


The sequence of performing eFAST is as follows-
  • Subxiphoid transverse view to look for any pericardial effusion.
  • Right upper quadrant- To look for any liver parenchymal injury, renal laceration or fluid in Morisson's pouch. 
  • Left upper quadrant- To look for any splenic or left renal injury. 
  • Suprapubic region- To look for any fluid in Pouch of Doughlas. 
  • Apart from these, left and right hemothorax for hemothorax and pneumothorax.
 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 378.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the trauma bay following a high-speed motor vehicle collision.
