He is hemodynamically unstable with signs of abdominal distension. A trauma CT scan reveals retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Identify the region marked in the picture that represents zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Marked region ‘A’ represents the zone 4 of retroperitoneal hemorrhage.


The classical division of retroperitoneal spaces in trauma surgery is into three zones:

  1. Zone 1 (Central):

    • From the esophageal hiatus to the sacral promontory.

    • Contains aorta, IVC, pancreas, duodenum, and portal structures.

  2. Zone 2 (Lateral or Perirenal):

    • From the lateral diaphragm to the iliac crest.

    • Includes the kidneys, ureters, and adrenal glands.

  3. Zone 3 (Pelvic):

    • Confined to the retroperitoneal pelvis.

    • Includes the iliac vessels and presacral veins.

Some expanded classifications introduce:

  • Zone 4 as the retrohepatic or portal region (sometimes also considered part of central Zone 1 in simplified schemes).

  • Alternatively, Zone 4 may also be used specifically for the retrohepatic IVC area or posterior abdominal wall/spinal region — but this is less standardized and varies by source.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents who report swelling in his right groin area noticed for the past few months. The swelling increases when the child cries or stands for a long time and reduces on lying down. On examination, a reducible inguinal swelling is noted, and transillumination test is positive. Ultrasound confirms the presence of a hernia with hydrocele. What is the line of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Management of hydrocele of the hernia sac (congenital hydrocele) in a 3 years old child is herniotomy.
 
  • A patent processus vaginalis may allow only peritoneal fluid to track down around the testis to form a hydrocoele.
  • Hydrocele are unilateral or bilateral, asymptomatic, tender scrotal swellings.
  • They may be tense or lax, but typically transilluminate.
  • The majority resolve spontaneously as the processus continues to obliterate, but surgical ligation is recommended in boys older than three years of age.
Other options: 
 

  • Herniorrhaphy (repair with reinforcement, usually with mesh) is typically done in adults, not in young children.

  • Observation is not advised once a hernia is confirmed due to risk of incarceration.

  • Waiting until 5 years of age is not appropriate for hernias; early surgery is preferred to avoid complications.


Fig: Hydrocele

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 256.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man underwent wide local excision of a squamous cell carcinoma involving the upper central chest wall, resulting in a large soft tissue defect with exposed ribs. Which flap was used to accomplish chest wall closure in the patient depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap
 
  • Based on the provided image, the chest wall closure was achieved using a pectoralis major myocutaneous flap (Option C).
  • The pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is a versatile reconstructive option commonly used for chest wall defects, particularly following tumor resection or trauma.
  • It is based on the thoracoacromial artery and can be rotated superiorly or medially to cover soft tissue defects following oncologic resections like mastectomy or excision of chest wall tumors.
  • The other options mentioned, such as transversely oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap (Option A), vertically oriented rectus abdominis muscle flap (Option B), and serratus anterior muscle flap (Option D), are different types of muscle flaps that can be used for various reconstructive purposes but are not specifically indicated for chest wall closure.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image
questions.solution:
Mixter Forceps (also known as "Mixter clamp" or "Right-angle clamp") are a type of surgical instrument used primarily for clamping, grasping, and dissecting tissues during surgical procedures. These forceps have a right-angle shape, which allows for precise manipulation of structures in hard-to-reach places. The angled tips give the surgeon the ability to work around other structures without causing damage.

Clinical Use:

  • Urological Surgery: For grasping and manipulating ureters, particularly during procedures such as nephrectomies or cystectomies.

  • Vascular Surgery: For clamping arteries or veins, particularly in small or delicate vessels.

  • Gynecological Surgery: To grasp tissues or vessels during procedures like hysterectomies.




Adson‘s forceps, also known as Cerci-Adson:Brown forceps, feature a double grasping tip for enhanced stabilization. They are particularly suited for grasping cartilage during rhinoplasty, as their multi-teeth tip minimizes cartilage damage and prevents bounce.



Kocher's forceps are designed with opposing teeth at the tip and serrations on the distal blades. They are used to hold pedicles, tough structures, and cut ends of muscles. Additionally, they are useful for holding ribs during rib dissection and securing resected bowel.


Rampley‘s sponge-holding forceps have a fenestrated, serrated, and flat end. They are used for:

a)Mopping oozing areas

b)Holding the gallbladder and cervix during surgeries

c)Performing blunt dissections



Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page no 1150 ,1146,1147 .

choices.text: Massive transfusion of blood and blood products

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a road traffic accident. He is conscious but shows signs of massive hemorrhage with significant blood loss. What should not be done?
questions.solution:
Injudicious use of crystalloid during resuscitation has been shown to exacerbate the systemic insult in response to hemorrhagic shock, including worsened cardiac function, pulmonary complications, gastric dysmotility, abdominal compartment syndrome, dilutional coagulopathy, immunological and inflammatory dysfunction. For trauma patients with massive hemorrhage, the primary goal should be the use of blood products (whole blood, packed red blood cells, etc.) rather than excessive crystalloid administration.
According to the Latest (10th edition) ATLS guidelines "Infusion of more than 1.5 liters of crystalloid has been associated with increased mortality."

Other options: 

  • Massive transfusion of blood and blood products: This is often indicated in cases of massive hemorrhage. Blood transfusion helps replace lost blood volume, and blood products (such as platelets, plasma) are critical to control bleeding and maintain circulation.

  • Early tranexamic acid recommended: This is a standard treatment in trauma. Tranexamic acid should be given early to help prevent excessive bleeding by inhibiting fibrinolysis. Studies show it improves outcomes when given within 3 hours of injury.

  • Check coagulation with thromboelastography, if available: Thromboelastography (TEG) or ROTEM (rotational thromboelastometry) are useful diagnostic tools to assess the viscoelastic properties of blood clotting. They can help guide transfusion decisions in trauma patients and allow for targeted therapy, such as the administration of specific clotting factors or blood products. Using TEG early in massive hemorrhage management can help optimize care by tailoring the resuscitation strategy based on the patient’s specific coagulation status.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 16.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lactating woman presents with a painful, firm lump in her right breast that she has noticed over the past few days. She is breastfeeding her infant and reports localized swelling and tenderness. On physical examination, there is a palpable, tender lump in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. There are no signs of fever or systemic illness. What is the most appropriate initial investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) USG
 

In a lactating woman presenting with a painful breast lump, the most appropriate initial investigation is ultrasonography (USG). This is because ultrasound is highly effective for evaluating breast lumps in young women and lactating mothers, where dense breast tissue is common, and it helps distinguish between cystic (e.g., breast abscess, galactocele) and solid masses (e.g., fibroadenoma, mastitis). It also guides needle aspiration if required.

  • Mammography is not the first choice for lactating women due to the dense nature of the breast tissue, which makes it less sensitive and harder to interpret. It is typically reserved for women over 40 or for suspicious cases where further investigation is required.

  • MRI is used for complex cases or when further characterization of the lesion is needed, but it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for a painful breast lump in a lactating woman.

  • X-ray is not a diagnostic tool for breast evaluation and is not indicated in this case.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with a complaint of continuous urine dribbling throughout the day. Her parents report that, despite normal voiding patterns, she has never been completely dry since birth. There is no history of urinary tract infections, and the dribbling persists even when she is not attempting to urinate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ectopic Ureteric Orifice (Option 1):
  • Most likely diagnosis in this case.
  • Occurs when the ureter drains into an abnormal location, such as the vagina, vulva, or urethra, leading to continuous urinary dribbling.
  • Characteristic feature: Continuous dribbling of urine despite normal voiding, as described in this patient.
  • Usually presents in infancy or early childhood.
  • IVU can be used for investigation
  • Re-implantation of the ectopic ureter is the definitive treatment.


Other options: 
Option 2: Ureterocele, while a congenital abnormality of the distal ureter that causes a cystic swelling within the bladder, tends to present with symptoms like urinary tract infections or obstruction, rather than continuous dribbling.
Option 3: Congenital megaureter is characterized by an abnormal dilation of the ureter, typically leading to urinary tract infections or hydronephrosis, but does not usually cause continuous dribbling of urine.
Option 4: Vesicoureteric reflux involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, which often presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and symptoms like urgency or frequency, not continuous dribbling.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1498.

questions.text: All of the following pathological lesions given below are premalignant with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn's disease
 
  • Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory condition that primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract, but it is not typically associated with premalignant changes. It can lead to complications such as strictures and fistulas but does not have a direct premalignant potential like the other conditions listed.

  • Ulcerative colitis is associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer due to chronic inflammation.

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with hamartomatous polyps and an increased risk of various cancers, including colorectal cancer.

  • Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition that increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671, 1268.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis B presents to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, fatigue, and an increasing abdominal girth. Imaging reveals a suspicious lesion in the liver, and the patient is suspected of having hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Which one of the following statements about HCC is true?
(i) Global incidence of HCC is rising
(ii) NASH & NAFLD are risk factors
(iii) LENVATINIB is used in tumors of size < 3.5 cm
(iv) TACE is done for multi-modular tumor
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. i, ii, iv

  • (i) Global incidence of HCC is rising: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide, particularly in regions where chronic viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B and C) and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are common.
  • (ii) NASH & NAFLD are risk factors: True. Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are significant risk factors for the development of HCC, particularly in the context of obesity and metabolic syndrome.
  • (iv) TACE is done for multi-modular tumor: True. Transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) is often used for the management of multi-nodular or inoperable HCC, as it can help reduce tumor size and improve symptoms.

Management of HCC:

1. Localised disease—Small tumors are resected by maintaining functional liver reserve (>25%) .In case of low functional liver reserve, liver transplant is done . FLR can be increased by Nimura’s technique or ALPP’s procedure ( Associating Liver Partition and Portal vein ligation for Staged Hepatectomy ) in some cases.

2. Advanced disease—SUNITINIB, LENVATINIB, SORATENIB , TACE (Trans arterial chemo embolization ),TARE (Trans arterial radio embolization) and Radio frequency ablation.

Lenvatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for the treatment of advanced HCC, but its use is not specifically limited to tumors of less than 3.5 cm. It is used in various stages of HCC, particularly for patients who are not candidates for surgery or liver transplant.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1214.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who recently underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recovering in the post-operative ward. During her recovery, her urine output is being closely monitored. What is the ideal urine output for this patient?
questions.solution:
In post-operative patients, including those who undergo laparoscopic cholecystectomy, maintaining adequate urine output is essential to assess renal function and hydration status. The ideal urine output should typically range from 0.5-1.5 ml/kg/hour (Option 4) in adults, which ensures proper renal perfusion and helps prevent complications such as fluid overload or dehydration.

  • Option 1 (500 ml/day) is below the normal expected urine output in an adult and is inadequate for ensuring proper renal function.

  • Option 2 (0.5 ml/minute) is an overly high value, equivalent to 30 ml/hour, which is excessive and not typically aimed for in most adult patients.

  • Option 3 (1 ml/kg) is not incorrect but lacks the necessary time-based range for optimal fluid management.

 

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 331 .

choices.text: Clean and drape from the level of nipple to mid-thigh
Clean and drape from chin to knee
Clean and drape from umbilicus to mid-thigh
Clean and drape from rib cage to inguinal regions

questions.text: Using a midline laparotomy method, a surgeon chooses to operate on a patient with cancer cecum and execute a right hemicolectomy. To prepare the patient's body parts for surgery, you have been given instructions. How will you proceed?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Clean and drape from the level of nipple to mid thigh.

For a right hemicolectomy, which involves accessing the abdominal cavity, particularly the cecum, ascending colon, and ileocecal junction, a midline laparotomy approach is used. The draping should ensure that the entire abdominal area, including the upper and lower quadrants, is exposed to facilitate optimal surgical access.

Option 1 (Clean and drape from the level of nipple to mid-thigh) is the best choice as it ensures exposure of the entire abdominal cavity, allowing the surgeon to access the cecum, ascending colon, and ileum properly.
Option 2 (Clean and drape from chin to knee) is excessive and includes unnecessary areas, particularly the face and legs, which are not involved in this surgery.
Option 3 (Clean and drape from umbilicus to mid-thigh) would limit exposure of the upper abdomen, which is essential for a midline laparotomy approach.
Option 4 (Clean and drape from rib cage to inguinal regions) is also appropriate, but covering from the level of the nipple to mid-thigh ensures better access to both upper and lower quadrants of the abdomen, which may be necessary for the procedure.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1376.

choices.text: No breath-holding is required for the procedure
Platelet count of less than 40,000 is a contraindication
It is useful is diagnosis of infiltrative and granulomatous disorders
It can be done in both prone and lateral positions

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the procedure in which this needle is used?
questions.solution:
• This is Bone marrow aspiration needle / Jamshidi's needle. So, Platelet count < 40000 is not a contraindication for this procedure. 
  • Absolute contraindications to bone marrow biopsy and aspiration include severe bleeding diatheses such as severe hemophilia or severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.
  • Thrombocytopenia is rather in indication for performing bone marrow biopsy. 
Other options: 
  • Bone marrow aspiration does not require breath-holding, as the procedure is localized and the needle insertion is brief.
  • It is useful in diagnosing infiltrative and granulomatous disorders, such as tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, or metastatic cancer.
  • Bone marrow aspiration can be performed in both the prone and lateral positions depending on the patient's comfort and the site of aspiration (e.g., posterior iliac crest or anterior iliac crest).
Reference: 
Rindy LJ, Chambers AR. Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy. [Updated 2023 May 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is present only in pregnancy with heart disease and not in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease, but not seen in normal pregnancy.

Because of heart disease, mainly right sided heart failure, increased jugular venous pressure upto + 5cm is seen due to high cardiac output causing neck vein distension.

Other options: 

  • Exertional dyspnea can be seen in normal pregnancy due to the increased metabolic demands and changes in lung function, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

  • Pedal edema is common in normal pregnancy due to the increased fluid retention and pressure from the expanding uterus, and it is not a specific indicator of heart disease.

  • Supine hypotension occurs due to the compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus when the patient is lying on their back and is common in normal pregnancy.



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 60.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents for routine examination at 36 weeks of gestation. During the pelvic examination, the obstetrician is measuring the dimensions of the pelvic inlet. Which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
• The obstetric conjugate is the shortest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet.
  • It is measured from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the posterior aspect of the pubic symphysis.
  • It is important in obstetrics as it determines whether the fetal head can pass through the pelvic inlet during childbirth.
 

  • True conjugate is a measurement from the sacral promontory to the anterior surface of the symphysis pubis. It is slightly longer than the obstetric conjugate and is less clinically relevant for obstetric practice.

  • Anatomical conjugate is another term for the true conjugate, which is also not the shortest diameter.

  • Bispinous diameter refers to the distance between the two ischial spines, which measures the transverse diameter of the pelvic inlet and is unrelated to the anteroposterior measurements.



    DIAGONAL CONJUGATE: 

  • The diagonal conjugate is measured from the lower edge of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory, which is the upper part of the sacrum. It is the only diameter of the pelvic inlet which can be measured clinically. 

  • It is slightly longer than the obstetric conjugate and is not a direct measurement of the shortest diameter that affects fetal passage during childbirth, but it provides an estimate.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic for a routine gynecological examination. She has no complaints and her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. You decide to perform a Pap smear as part of cervical cancer screening. What is the proper order for the PAP smear steps?
i. Take the sample
ii. Retract vagina
iii. Fixation
iv. Make smear on the slide
questions.solution:
Steps of taking Pap smear 

Procedure:
Undress completely or only from the waist down
                               \(\downarrow\)

Lie down on your back on an exam table with knees bent 
(lithotomy position). Heels rest in supports called stirrups 
                                \(\downarrow\)
Insert speculum into vagina. The speculum holds the walls of
your vagina apart so that doctor can easily see cervix
                                \(\downarrow\)
Take samples of your cervical cells using a soft brush and a flat
scarping device called a spatula, make a slide, Fix in 95% ethyl alcohol 




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7.

choices.text: Forceps can be used for > 15 degree head rotation from AP diameter
Can be used in vertex, mento-anterior face presentation
Should not be used with caput succedaneum

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for an elective forceps delivery in a cephalic foetus?
questions.solution:
Can be used in vertex, mento-anterior and face presentation
Rest all statements are false.
                               
Classification of Operative Vaginal Deliveries
Types of Procedure Criteria
Outlet 1. Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
2. Fetal skull has reached the level of the pelvic floor 
3. Sagittal suture is in the direct anteroposterior diameter or in the right or left occiput anterior and posterior position 
4. Fetal head is at or on the perineum
5. Rotation is \(\leq 45^{\circ}\)
Low Leading point of the fetal skull (station) is station +2/+5 or more but has not as yet reached the pelvic floor
(a) Rotation is \(\leq 45^{\circ}\)
(b) Rotation is > 45°
Midpelvic The head is engaged in the pelvis but the presenting part is above +2 station 
High (High included in the classification)



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 534.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the HPE given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Malignant teratoma
 
  • Malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary composed of cells from the three germ layers, containing variable amounts of mature and immature tissue
  • Affects mostly young females < 20 years old
  • Grossly solid ovarian tumor mass with necrosis and hemorrhage on cut sections
  • Grading is performed based on the amount of immature neuroepithelium
  • Can have associated nodal or peritoneal gliomatosis (presence of mature neural tissue), which increases risk of recurrence
  • Grading and stage are the most important factors for prognosis, greatly improved after chemotherapy
Histopathological findings in Malignant Teratoma:
 
  • Immature Tissue Elements: Presence of primitive neuroectodermal tissue (neuroblasts, rosettes) and immature mesenchymal or epithelial tissue.
  • Malignant Components: Somatic malignancies such as squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, or sarcomas within the teratoma.
  • High-Grade Features: Cellular pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic activity.
  • Necrosis and Hemorrhage: Common in malignant areas, reflecting the aggressive nature of the tumor.
Other options: 
 

  • Dysgerminoma: Uniform large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei; fibrous septa with lymphocytes; no immature elements.

  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor): Shows Schiller-Duval bodies and AFP positivity; not neuroectodermal tissue.

  • Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: Shows glandular architecture with mucin-producing epithelial cells, not neural/mesenchymal tissue.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 461.

questions.text: A 27-year-old G2P1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with regular uterine contractions occurring every 10 minutes for the past 3 hours. On examination, she is afebrile, fetal heart rate is normal, and her cervix is 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. She has no history of trauma or rupture of membranes. What dose of dexamethasone is given to this woman in threatened preterm labour?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
 

To enhance fetal lung maturity in pregnancies at risk of preterm birth (between 24–34 weeks of gestation), antenatal corticosteroids are recommended.

Two main corticosteroid regimens are used:

  1. Betamethasone – 12 mg IM every 24 hours × 2 doses

  2. Dexamethasone – 6 mg IM every 12 hours × 4 doses

Antenatal corticosteroids significantly decrease the risk of: 
RDS - Respiratory Distress Syndrome 
NEC - Necrotising Enterocolitis
BPD - Broncho-Pulmonary Dysplasia
IVH - Intra-Ventricular Haemorrhage

Overall, corticosteroid administration lowers neonatal mortality and the need for intensive care interventions, improving short- and long-term outcomes in preterm neonates.



Steroid dosage Memorizing Trick-
Dexamethasone- Dexa similar to Hexa- 6- 6 mg every 12 hours 4 injections
Betamethasone- B- 2nd letter of albhabet- 2 dosage twice the dose of Dexa and gap- 12 mg 2 injections 24 hours apart



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 802.

questions.text: Studies have demonstrated that the timing of a caesarean section has no impact on prematurity-related problems such IUGR. At which gestational age should a cesarean section ideally be performed?
questions.solution:
The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the National Institute of Health recommend that non-medically indicated elective Caesarean Delivery should be performed after 39 weeks’ gestation to reduce neonatal respiratory morbidity and mortality rates.
 

This timing minimizes the risk of neonatal respiratory complications, including transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) and respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), which are more common when cesarean is done earlier without labor.

Although intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is a pathological condition, its management does not warrant early cesarean solely to avoid prematurity-related issues—unless there are signs of fetal compromise.

Why not before 39 weeks?
Delivering via cesarean before 39 weeks increases the risk of prematurity-related complications unless there is a medical or obstetric indication (like non-reassuring fetal status, severe preeclampsia, placental abruption, etc.).

In uncomplicated pregnancies, waiting until 39 weeks allows full fetal lung maturity and reduces NICU admissions.


EXTRA EDGE: 
The ARRIVE trial (A Randomized Trial of Induction Versus Expectant Management) was a large, multi-center, randomized controlled trial that sought to determine whether inducing labor at 39 weeks in low-risk women would lead to better outcomes for the mother and baby compared to the traditional approach of waiting for spontaneous labor to occur after 39 weeks.
The ARRIVE trial provides evidence supporting the practice of elective induction at 39 weeks in low-risk women to reduce the likelihood of cesarean delivery without negatively affecting neonatal outcomes. This has influenced current guidelines and practices in obstetrics, as it helps clinicians make informed decisions about timing for induction, especially in uncomplicated pregnancies.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 549.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female at 39 weeks of gestation is in labor and has been administered opioid analgesia for pain management. Which of the following medications should be kept on hand in case of emergency?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Naloxone
 
  • Naloxone is a medicine that rapidly reverses an opioid overdose. It is an opioid antagonist. This means that it attaches to opioid receptors and reverses and blocks the effects of other opioids.
  • Naloxone can quickly restore normal breathing to a person if their breathing has slowed or stopped because of an opioid overdose.
  • Narcotics used during labor may cause newborn respiratory depression. Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system.
  • After adequate ventilation has been established, naloxone may be given to a newborn whose mother received narcotics.
  • Naloxone is contraindicated in a newborn of a narcotic-addicted mother because withdrawal symptoms may be precipitated (American Academy of Pediatrics, 2017).
Other options: 

  • Fentanyl and Morphine are both opioids and would only worsen the patient's condition if administered again in case of overdose.

  • Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic and may be used in labor epidurals but does not address the opioid-related complications like respiratory depression.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 469, 1150.

choices.text: Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and expedite the delivery
Injection labetalol , antenatal steroids, and immediate termination of pregnancy
Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and deliver at 37 weeks
Injection labetalol to control her blood pressure

questions.text: A 34 year old primigravida with chronic hypertension came to the hospital at 37 weeks of gestation with headache and blurring vision. Her BP is 180/110 mm Hg. Urine analysis reveals urine albumin 3+. What is the next step to be done?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option 1: Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and expedite the delivery.

This patient presents with severe preeclampsia, which is characterized by:

  • Severe hypertension (BP ≥ 160/110 mm Hg).

  • Proteinuria (3+ on urine analysis).

  • Symptoms of end-organ damage, including headache and blurred vision, which are indicative of potential cerebral involvement (e.g., hypertensive encephalopathy).

    Next steps in management include:

  1. Blood pressure control: The patient’s blood pressure should be lowered to prevent further end-organ damage. Labetalol is commonly used for blood pressure control in such cases.

  2. Seizure prophylaxis: Magnesium sulfate should be administered to prevent eclampsia, which is a risk in severe preeclampsia.

  3. Delivery: The most definitive treatment for preeclampsia is delivery. Since the patient is 37 weeks pregnant, she should be delivered expeditiously. In severe preeclampsia, immediate delivery is warranted, and it is appropriate to expedite delivery at this gestational age.

    Other options: 

  • Option 2 (Injection labetalol, antenatal steroids, and immediate termination of pregnancy) involves the use of antenatal steroids, which are indicated for preterm labor to enhance fetal lung maturity. However, in this case, the patient is already at 37 weeks, where the fetus is considered term. Immediate termination is not necessary as delivery at this point is the goal.

  • Option 3 (Injection labetalol and magnesium sulfate and deliver at 37 weeks) is incorrect because the phrase "deliver at 37 weeks" does not indicate the urgency of the need for expediting delivery in a severe preeclampsia case.

  • Option 4 (Injection labetalol to control her blood pressure) is insufficient, as controlling blood pressure alone is not enough. Magnesium sulfate is also necessary for seizure prophylaxis, and delivery is the ultimate treatment for preeclampsia with severe features.



Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 690,716.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain. After undergoing a thorough evaluation, she is diagnosed with stage IIIB cervical carcinoma. The tumor is found to extend beyond the cervix to the pelvic wall and causes hydronephrosis due to obstruction of the ureters. There is no distant metastasis. What is included in the treatment of cervical carcinoma stage IIIB?
questions.solution:
Treatment of carcinoma cervix stage IIIB include: 4. concurrent chemoradiation

 

According to recent data, "concurrent chemotherapy" dramatically extends a woman's overall and disease-free survival in case she has advanced cervical cancer.

  • Concurrent chemoradiation is the gold standard treatment for stage IIIB cervical carcinoma. This approach involves:

    • Radiotherapy: External beam radiotherapy (EBRT) is administered to the pelvis, targeting both the primary tumor and any involved regional lymph nodes. Brachytherapy (internal radiation) is also given to directly irradiate the cervix and surrounding tissues.

    • Chemotherapy: The chemotherapeutic agent cisplatin is typically used in combination with radiotherapy. Chemotherapy enhances the effect of radiation and helps to treat micrometastases that may not be visible on imaging.

The rationale for this treatment approach is that stage IIIB cervical cancer is usually too advanced for surgery alone and may involve structures such as the pelvic wall or ureters, making it unsuitable for surgical resection.

 
Stage Treatment
Stage IA1 Surgery, total hysterectomy, and conization
Early disease Stage IA2,
IB or IIA		 Combined external beam radiation with brachytherapy and radical hysterectomy with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy for patients with stage IB or IIA diseae
Radical vaginal trachelectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection is appropriate for fertility preservation in women with stage IA2 disease and those with stage IB1 disease whose lesions are \(\leq\)2 cm
Cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radiation for stage IA-IIA patients who have specific high-risk features (positive) lymph nodes, surgical margins, and/or parametria)
Advanced disease Stage IIB, III,
or IVA		 Cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radiation
Metastatic disease Stage IVB and
recurrent cancer		 Cisplatin on a palliative basis, radiation therapy for control of bleeding and pain, and systemic chemotherapy for disseminated disease including cisplatin, paclitaxel, carboplatin, docetacel, topotecan, and bevacizumab



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 427, 429.

questions.text:
Match the hormonal profile of a 25-year-old woman who has amenorrhea.
A. Sheehan syndrome 1. low LH, low FSH, low Estrogen
B. Asherman syndrome 2. All are normal
C.PCOS 3. High LH, Normal FSH, Normal to high estrogen
D. Ovarian insuficiency 4. High LH and FSH, Low estrogen
questions.solution:
• A. Sheehan syndrome: 1. Low LH, low FSH, low Estrogen

    • Sheehan syndrome is due to pituitary infarction, usually following postpartum hemorrhage. The pituitary gland is unable to secrete adequate amounts of LH, FSH, and estrogen, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This results in low LH, low FSH, and low estrogen levels.

  • B. Asherman syndrome: 2. All are normal

    • Asherman syndrome is characterized by uterine adhesions typically caused by trauma (e.g., post-D&C). The hormonal profile is typically normal, as the ovaries are functioning properly. Amenorrhea results from the inability of the uterus to shed the endometrial lining due to the adhesions.

  • C. PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): 3. High LH, Normal FSH, Normal to high estrogen

    • In PCOS, there is elevated LH levels due to abnormal gonadotropin secretion, while FSH remains normal. The estrogen levels are typically normal to high, often because of the accumulation of estrogen in the ovaries, although it may be imbalanced with progesterone, contributing to anovulation.

  • D. Ovarian insufficiency (Premature ovarian failure): 4. High LH and FSH, Low estrogen

    • In ovarian insufficiency, there is loss of ovarian function leading to low estrogen production. The body responds by increasing LH and FSH secretion in an attempt to stimulate the ovaries, but they are unable to respond, resulting in elevated LH and FSH levels with low estrogen.

Tabular comparison:



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 16th edition, Page no 257, 329, 330, 331, 431, 432.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of infertility and cyclical discomfort, along with dysmenorrhea. She reports that the pain is most severe during menstruation and has gradually worsened over time. Which one of the following would be an option for her investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Diagnostic laproscopy

  • Infertility as well as cyclical discomfort and dysmenorrheal symptoms are suggestive of Endometriosis.
  • Laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endometriosis. TVS cannot detect endometriosis. 
  • The diagnosis should be validated by peritoneal and tissue biopsy because corpus luteal hematoma can resemble a chocolate cyst.

Role of laparoscopy: 

• To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
• Locate the site of endometriosis and staging
• To take biopsy.
• To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation and removal

Therefore, Laparoscopy is considered a gold standard for diagnosis of endometriosis.

Other options:

  • TVS: While TVS can be useful in identifying ovarian cysts (e.g., endometriomas) or other structural issues, it cannot definitively diagnose endometriosis.

  • Aspirate from pouch of Douglas: Aspiration of the pouch of Douglas is not a routine diagnostic approach and would not be helpful in diagnosing endometriosis.

  • Hormonal assessment: Hormonal assessments might help in other conditions (e.g., thyroid disorders, polycystic ovary syndrome), but they are not specific for diagnosing endometriosis.




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 178-180.

choices.text: Elective cesarean section has no effect in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury
GDM patient should be given morning dose of insulin at the time of induction as usual
Regular insulin is given by IV infusion pump

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a known history of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) presents in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. She has been well-controlled with diet and insulin therapy throughout her pregnancy. The patient is now being prepared for delivery. Regarding the management of a diabetic woman in labour which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
GDM patients should not be given a morning dose of insulin at the time of induction.
 
  • Because during the latent phase of labor, the metabolic demands are stable but during active labor there is increased metabolic demand and decreased insulin requirement.
  • The usual morning dose of insulin should be held or adjusted when a diabetic patient is admitted for labor induction. Insulin needs change during labor, and giving a full dose of insulin can result in hypoglycemia. Instead, regular monitoring of blood glucose and the use of IV regular insulin should be implemented for better control.
Other options:

  • Option 1: Elective cesarean section does not significantly reduce the incidence of brachial plexus injury in GDM patients, as the injury is more related to macrosomia and shoulder dystocia, which can occur in both vaginal and cesarean deliveries.

  • Option 3: Regular insulin is typically given by IV infusion pump during labor to allow precise control over blood glucose levels.

  • Option 4: Blood glucose levels are typically maintained between 90-110 mg/dL during labor in diabetic patients to avoid both hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia, ensuring fetal safety.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 332 .

questions.text: The stages of labour are depicted in the following graph. Which of the following claims about the graph C is true?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Secondary arrest after progression of labor
 

Secondary arrest of labor is defined as: No cervical dilation for more than 2 hours during the active phase of labor after previous normal progression.

Key Features (as seen in Graph C):

  • Cervical dilation progresses normally initially.

  • Then plateaus/stalls despite regular uterine contractions.

  • The patient is in active phase  when arrest occurs.

    Causes:

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)

  • Malpresentation (e.g., occipitoposterior)

  • Ineffective uterine contractions

  • Fetal macrosomia

  • Epidural-related hypotonia (less common)



   



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 401, 434-437.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used ?
questions.solution:
• Pulsatile GnRH administration mimics natural hypothalamic secretion, stimulating the pituitary to release FSH and LH, which in turn promotes spermatogenesis in males with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. 

    Other indications: 

  • Female anovulation due to hypothalamic amenorrhea (e.g. Kallmann syndrome)

  • Some cases of delayed puberty

  • Given via portable infusion pump every 60–90 mins IV or SC.

  • In contrast: Continuous GnRH suppresses FSH/LH and is used in endometriosis, precocious puberty, and prostate cancer for its downregulatory effects.



Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th edition, Page no 677, 678.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman visits the clinic for her first prenatal appointment. She reports that her last menstrual period (LMP) was on September 1, 2017. She has regular 28-day cycles. Using Naegele’s rule, what is her estimated date of delivery (EDD)?
questions.solution:
Naegele’s Rule?
It is a formula used to estimate the expected date of delivery (EDD) based on the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP) for women with regular 28-day cycles.


Due Date of Delivery = First Day of Last Menstrual Cycle + 9 months + 7 days

Thus the date is 8th June 2018.
50% of the deliveries occur in week before and after the Expected Date of Delivery. 

Important points:

  • This rule assumes a regular 28-day cycle.

  • If cycles are longer or shorter, adjustments must be made accordingly.

  • Not reliable in cases of:

    • Irregular cycles

    • Conception via ART (Assisted Reproduction Techniques)

    • Uncertain LMP

      Always confirm EDD with first trimester ultrasound (using CRL or Crown-Rump Length) if available—it provides the most accurate dating.



Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 122

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1 woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) diagnosed at 28 weeks and is currently on insulin therapy. Her glucose levels have remained within the recommended range with good compliance. Fetal growth and amniotic fluid index are within normal limits on ultrasound. There are no signs of preeclampsia or other complications. When should delivery be planned for this patient?
questions.solution:
NICE recommends that  pregnancy in diabetic women controlled on insulin should be terminated at 38 weeks.
 

  • Timing of delivery: In well-controlled GDM on Insulin, delivery is often planned at 38 weeks. This reduces the risk of macrosomia (which can lead to shoulder dystocia, birth trauma, and the need for cesarean delivery) and fetal distress while still allowing the fetus enough time to fully mature.

  • Monitoring for complications: Even with good glucose control, the fetus can still be at risk of overgrowth and other complications related to gestational diabetes, which may increase if pregnancy is prolonged beyond 38 weeks.

  • Induction of labor: If there are no contraindications and the pregnancy is uncomplicated (like in this case, where the fetal growth and amniotic fluid index are normal), 38 weeks is often considered the ideal timing for delivery, as it balances the risks associated with diabetes and avoids the potential complications of continuing the pregnancy longer.


Delivery:
• Timing of delivery depends on control
        If on insulin, the pregnancy is best terminated by 39>38 weeks
        If diet control is adequate then the pregnancy may be prolonged to term (39-40 weeks)
• Mode of delivery depends on clinical judgement
• Diabetes itself is not an indication for caesarean
• Factors favoring an elective CS are:
– Macrosomia
– Suspicion of cephalopelvic disproportion
– Malpresentation
– Polyhydramnios



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1078.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in labor at 39 weeks of gestation. After discussing the delivery plan, the obstetrician decides to perform an episiotomy to facilitate delivery. Which of the following distinguishes the mediolateral episiotomy from the midline episiotomy?
questions.solution:
Less chance of extension (Option 1):
The mediolateral episiotomy has a lower risk of extension into the anus (third or fourth-degree lacerations) compared to the midline episiotomy. This is one of its primary advantages, making it the preferred choice in many cases, especially for primigravidas.

Other options: 

Option 2: Can be repaired with ease: While both types of episiotomies can be repaired, the midline episiotomy is often easier to repair due to its straight line, which may offer a cleaner closure.

Option 3: Fewer breakdowns: The midline episiotomy can have a higher risk of wound dehiscence or breakdown compared to the mediolateral episiotomy because it is more prone to opening due to the tension from the surrounding tissues.

Option 4: Lesser blood loss: There is generally no significant difference in blood loss between the two types of episiotomy, as both involve incising the perineum, although midline episiotomy might theoretically involve slightly less blood loss due to the less extensive incision.


Comparison of Midline v/s Mediolateral Episiotomy



         
 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 509, 510.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent miscarriages and intermittent calf pain. She denies any other significant medical history but is concerned about her ability to carry a pregnancy to term. On physical examination, mild tenderness is noted in the calf, and there is no swelling or redness. The physician suspects a congenital clotting disorder. Which of the following congenital deficiencies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Protein C
 
  • Protein C is a vitamin K-dependent glycoprotein synthesized by liver that inactivates factors Va and VIlla. It is an anticoagulant and it's deficiency causes hypercoagulable state. Protein C deficiency is also an autosomal dominant genetic disorder that affects 3.2% of patients with venous thromboembolism.
  • Clinical signs and symptoms of Protein C deficiency vary and can range from mild to severe. Symptoms may include easy bruising and/or bleeding, superficial blood vessels that are visible on the skin, recurrent DVT ("deep vein thrombosis"), pulmonary embolism, recurrent miscarriages, stroke, or heart attack.
  • In infants, Protein C deficiency can cause a condition known as "purpura fulminans" which is characterized by severe abdominal pain, shock, and death within a few days of birth.
Other options: 

  • Option 2: Thrombin: It is a key enzyme in the clotting cascade that converts fibrinogen to fibrin, leading to clot formation. Its deficiency is rare and does not typically cause recurrent miscarriages or thrombosis.

  • Option 3: Plasmin: Its deficiency leads to impaired fibrinolysis, potentially causing excessive clotting, but it's not associated with recurrent miscarriages or thrombosis.

  • Option 4: Factor XIII: Deficiency causes bleeding disorders and poor wound healing, not recurrent pregnancy loss or thrombotic events.


List of Thrombophilias associated with RPL

  1. Protein C deficiency

  2. Protein S deficiency

  3. Antithrombin III deficiency

  4. Factor V Leiden mutation

  5. Prothrombin gene mutation (G20210A)

  6. Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 976, 977.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 319, 376.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with abdominal bloating, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss. Imaging reveals a pelvic mass and elevated CA-125 levels, raising suspicion for ovarian cancer. During surgery, a mass is found confined to the ovaries, with no visible spread to other organs. Peritoneal cytology reveals the presence of carcinoma cells. Given these findings, what stage is the patient classified as according to the FIGO staging system for ovarian cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Stage IC3

According to the latest staging system that is based on the FIGO (International Federation of Obstetrics and Gynecology) classification, Stage IC3 (positive peritoneal cytology) indicates the stage where ovarian cancer is confined to the ovary but with peritoneal cytology showing positive results for cancer cells, even without macroscopic peritoneal involvement.

FIGO Staging for Ovarian CA: 
 
STAGE DESCRIPTION
I Tumor confined to ovaries or fallopian tube(s)
IA Tumor limited to 1 ovary (capsule intact) or fallopian tube; no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface; no malignant cells in the ascites or peritoneal washings
IB Tumor limited to both ovaries (capsules intact) or fallopian tubes; no tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface; no malignant cells in the ascites or peritoneal washings
IC Tumor limited to 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, with any of the following
IC1 Surgical spill
IC2 Capsule ruptured before surgery or tumor on ovarian or fallopian tube surface
IC3 Malignant cells in the ascites or peritoneal washings
II Tumor involves 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes with pelvic extension (below pelvic brim) or peritoneal cancer
IIA Extension and/or implants on uterus and/or fallopian tubes and/or ovaries
IIB Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
III Tumor involves 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, or peritoneal cancer, with cytologically or histologically confirmed spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and/or metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes
IIIA Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only (cytologically or histologically proven)
IIIA1(i) Metastasis up to 10 mm in greatest dimension
IIIA1(i) Metastasis more than 10 mm in greatest dimension
IIIA2 Microscopic extrapelvic (above the pelvic brim) peritoneal involvement with or without positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes
IIIB Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis up to 2 cm in greatest dimension, with or without metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes
IIIC Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond the pelvis more than 2 cm in greatest dimension, with or without metasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes (includes extension of tumor to capsule of liver and spleen without parenchymal involvement of either organ)
IV Distant metastasis excluding peritoneal metastases
IVA Pleural effusion with positive cytology
IVB Parenchymal metastases and metastases to extra-abdominal organs (including inguinal lymph nodes and lymph nodes outside of the abdominal cavity)





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 466.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of two first-trimester spontaneous abortions is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure and undergoes routine preoperative coagulation screening. Her lab results are as follows: PT = 15/14(Control), aPTT = 45/35(control), platelet count = 2.5 lac/mm3. What ailment does she probably have?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Anti-phospholipid syndrome
 
  • The patient in the question has a prolonged aPTT and a normal PT, which is consistent with a lupus anticoagulant. The patient also has a history of 2 first-trimester spontaneous abortions, which is a risk factor for APS.
  • Anti-phospholipid syndrome is an autoimmune disorder where the body produces antibodies against phospholipids, leading to a paradoxical increase in blood clotting, despite the name.
Other options: 

  1. Factor IX deficiency (Hemophilia B): Causes prolonged aPTT but typically presents in males with bleeding, not thrombosis or pregnancy loss.

  2. Von Willebrand disease type III: Causes severe bleeding and very low vWF levels → prolonged aPTT and bleeding history, not abortions.

  3. Factor VIII inhibitors: Also prolong aPTT but are associated with bleeding, not recurrent abortions.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2750.

choices.text: Amyloid Angiopathy is associated with Small Vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is associated with Amyloid Angiopathy
Alzheimer's Disease is related to small vessel disease
Alzheimer's Disease is not related to small vessel disease

questions.text: All of the following statements are are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• It has been seen that deposition of amyloid is aggravated in patients with cerebral small-vessel disease, especially in apolipoprotein E4 carriers, providing evidence for pathophysiological synergy between these three biological factors
  • The accumulation of Aβ in cerebral arterioles is termed amyloid angiopathy. Thus, amyloid angiopathy is a small vessel disease which is also seen in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
  • In Alzheimer's disease, microscopically, there are widespread neuritic plaques containing amyloid beta (Aβ), neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) composed of hyperphosphorylated tau filaments, and Aβ accumulation in blood vessel walls in cortex and leptomeninges (amyloid angiopathy).
  • Also, in many patients with AD, amyloid angiopathy can lead to microhemorrhages, large lobar hemorrhages, ischemic infarctions most often in the subcortical white matter, or in rare cases an inflammatory leukoencephalopathy.

  • Alzheimer’s disease is related to small vessel disease through overlapping pathologies (amyloid, ischemia, hypoperfusion).

    PATHOGENESIS OF ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3349, 3370-3372.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of giddiness for the past few days. He is a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years, managed with metformin. He denies any recent chest pain, palpitations, or visual disturbances. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. On examination, his blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, and pulse is regular. After counseling him on dietary and lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate initial antihypertensive medication?
questions.solution:
Newly diagnosed Hypertensive patient with history of T2DM, the best line of treatment wound be Amlodipine along with lifestyle modifications.

Why amlodipine?

  • Amlodipine is a long-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB).

  • Elderly-friendly: It does not cause orthostatic hypotension, making it ideal for elderly patients with symptoms like giddiness.

  • Safe in Diabetes: It doesn't affect blood glucose or mask hypoglycemia (unlike beta-blockers).

  • Effective BP Control: Amlodipine provides smooth 24-hour blood pressure control with once-daily dosing.

  • Preferred as First-Line: In diabetics without albuminuria, CCBs like amlodipine are preferred as first-line antihypertensives (as per JNC 8, ADA, and ESC guidelines).


Prazosin wound be contraindicated in this patient due to his history of dizziness as this drug can cause orthostatic hypotension.


Clonidine: Short-acting; risk of rebound hypertension, CNS side effects, and sedation. Avoid unless used acutely or in resistant hypertension.

Metoprolol: Beta-blockers are not first-line in diabetics unless there’s an indication like heart failure or post-MI status.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2082.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of sudden onset facial puffiness, pedal edema, and markedly reduced urine output. He has no significant past medical history. On examination, blood pressure is elevated at 165/100 mmHg, and periorbital edema is noted. Initial labs reveal elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria. A renal biopsy shows crescent formation in glomeruli, and immunofluorescence is negative for immune complex deposits, consistent with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis. Which of the following antibodies is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Anti Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody is the Most Common antibody associated with Pauci-Immune Cresentric Glomerulonephritis.

  • Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis is most commonly associated with ANCA-associated vasculitides (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis).

  • The hallmark is rapidly progressive renal failure (RPRF) with little or no immune deposits seen on immunofluorescence.

  • The most relevant antibodies are:

    • c-ANCA (PR3) – in granulomatosis with polyangiitis

    • p-ANCA (MPO) – in microscopic polyangiitis

Other options: 

ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) is most commonly positive in lupus nephritis, which is an immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis—not pauci-immune—and shows a full-house pattern on immunofluorescence.

Anti-GBM antibodies are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, which causes linear IgG deposition on immunofluorescence. This is not pauci-immune, and typically also presents with hemoptysis due to pulmonary hemorrhage.

Anti-PLA2R antibodies are specific for primary membranous nephropathy, which presents with nephrotic syndrome and subepithelial immune deposits—not crescent formation or rapid renal failure.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page. No- 909, 910.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with no significant past medical history is brought to the emergency department after he suddenly collapsed at home during an intense emotional argument with his brother. According to family members, he had complained of acute-onset substernal chest pain followed by light-headedness and loss of consciousness. Emergency services found him unresponsive, and resuscitation efforts were unsuccessful. He was pronounced dead on arrival. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as the apical ballooning syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a form of heart failure that is becoming more recognized around the world.
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome is characterized by a weakening of the heart muscle, specifically the left ventricle, causing it to temporarily balloon out, similar to a Japanese octopus trap (takotsubo). T
  • It is characterized by global ventricular dilation with basal contraction, and primarily affects older women following intense emotional or physical stress.
  • Symptoms may include pulmonary edema, chest pain, and hypotensive states and ECG changes that mimic an acute infarction.
  • The left ventricular impairment usually resolves within a few weeks, however it is considered to be a reversible condition.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 102, 1966.
Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1590.

choices.text: Painful genital and oral blisters and ulcers

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of polyarthritis. Laboratory testing reveals a nucleolar pattern of ANA staining. What is the most likely course of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Sclerodactyly, esophageal dysmotility, and Raynaud’s phenomenon
 
  • Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder characterized by fibrosis and vascular abnormalities causing sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers), esophageal dysmotility (difficulty swallowing due to impaired movement of the esophagus), and Raynaud's phenomenon (spasms in the blood vessels of the fingers or toes in response to cold or stress). Polyarthritis can also be a component of systemic sclerosis.
  • Systemic features like Polyarthritis are more diagnostic of Diffuse SSc rather than Limited SSc (CREST syndrome)
  • Moreover, In Diffuse SSc generally, Sclerodactyly is followed by Raynaud's phenomenon whereas in Limited SSc (CREST) Raynaud's phenomenon precedes much before other features.
  • The nucleolar pattern of ANA staining is associated with certain autoimmune conditions, including Systemic sclerosis.

The other options mentioned in the question correspond to different autoimmune conditions:
 
  • Option 1: Malar rash, alopecia, and renal failure are features seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). ANA pattern seen in SLE is typically homogeneous or speckled, not nucleolar.
  • Option 3: Sjögren’s syndrome → This presents with dry eyes and dry mouth and usually shows a speckled ANA pattern, not nucleolar.
  • Option 4: Painful genital and oral blisters and ulcers are associated with mucous membrane involvement in Behcet's disease, which is not associated with a nucleolar ANA pattern.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2776, 2778-2780.

choices.text: Immediately taper off valproate and start lamotrigine
Continue valproate and serial drug monitoring in blood

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida at 16 weeks of pregnancy presents for prenatal care. She has a known history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and has been on sodium valproate for many years, which has effectively controlled her seizures. She has just come in to ask for advice on changing her antiepileptic medication. Which advice do you have for her?
questions.solution:
• Continue valproate with serial drug monitoring in the blood of this 29 year old 4-month gravid patient having history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.
  • Most women with epilepsy who become pregnant will have an uncomplicated gestation and deliver a normal baby.
  • Changes in seizure frequency are attributed to endocrine effects on the CNS, variations in antiepileptic drug pharmacokinetics (such as acceleration of hepatic drug metabolism or effects on plasma protein binding), and changes in medication compliance.
  • Because the potential harm of uncontrolled convulsive seizures on the mother and fetus is considered greater than the teratogenic effects of antiseizure drugs, it is currently recommended that pregnant women be maintained on effective drug therapy.
  • Patients should also take folate (1–4 mg/d), because the antifolate effects of anticonvulsants are thought to play a role in the development of neural tube defects.
  • Lamotrigine and carbamazepine are often considered safer alternatives during pregnancy, but immediate discontinuation of valproate without a suitable replacement can increase the risk of seizures, which could be dangerous for both mother and fetus.
  • While adding lamotrigine to valproate may seem like a viable option for controlling seizures, the potential for drug interactions and increased toxicity makes it less favorable.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3320, 3323.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with relative bradycardia?
questions.solution:
• Relative bradycardia ( also known as Faget's sign) is uncommon in Staphylococcus infection as compared to given options.
 
  • Typhoid fever, brucellosis, leptospirosis, various drug-induced fevers, and factitious fever all exhibit temperature-pulse dissociation (relative bradycardia).
  • The mechanism is thought to involve autonomic nervous system dysfunction, endotoxin release, or central nervous system involvement.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 944.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after falling unconscious two hours ago. He reports experiencing a sudden, severe headache, which he describes as the "worst headache of my life." After regaining consciousness, he complains of neck rigidity and photophobia. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
 
  • In SAH, sudden loss of consciousness may be preceded by a brief moment of excruciating headache, but most patients first complain of headache upon regaining consciousness.
  • The patient often calls the headache “the worst headache of my life”; however, the most important characteristic is sudden onset.
  • NCCT head should be done in this case to confirm the diagnosis. On CT scans, subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) appears as a high-attenuating, amorphous substance that fills the normally dark, CSF-filled subarachnoid spaces around the brain. The normally black subarachnoid cisterns and sulci may appear white in acute hemorrhage.

Other Options:

Option 2. IV antibiotics → Indicated if there is suspicion of meningitis, but the clinical presentation suggests a more urgent need to rule out SAH first.

Option 3. Lumbar puncture → While lumbar puncture is the gold standard for diagnosing SAH if CT is negative, it should be performed after a non-contrast CT scan to rule out the presence of bleeding.

Option 4. IV mannitol → Used to reduce intracranial pressure in conditions like cerebral edema, but this patient needs diagnostic clarification (CT first) before treatment initiation.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in her legs. On examination, she has a prominent peripheral edema, and her oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Her chest X-ray shows enlarged pulmonary arteries, and echocardiography reveals right heart strain with elevated pulmonary artery pressures. She is diagnosed with primary pulmonary hypertension (PPH). Which of the following drugs can be administered to manage her condition?
questions.solution:
Bosentan can be given in patients of primary pulmonary hypertension.

  • Bosentan is a FDA approved non-specific antagonist of endothelin receptors (ERA) of both ET-A & ET-B. 
  • ERAs prevent ET-1 from attaching to either endothelin receptor A (ET-A) or receptor B(ET-B). Vasoconstriction is mediated by ET-A receptors on the smooth muscle cells of the pulmonary artery. ET-B receptors are found on endothelial cells in the normal pulmonary vasculature, and they were found to mediate vasodilation by the synthesis of prostacyclin and nitric oxide as well as the clearance of ET-1.
  • By inhibiting these receptors, bosentan reduces pulmonary vascular resistance and lowers the pressure in the lungs, leading to improved exercise tolerance and reduced symptoms.

  • Liver function tests are essential because bosentan can cause hepatotoxicity. It is contraindicated in patients with severe liver dysfunction.

  • Pregnancy: Bosentan is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential teratogenic effects.

  • Bosentan is also associated with anemia and requires periodic blood count monitoring.

Mechanism of action of BOSENTAN

Other Options:

Option 1. Icatibant → Used for Hereditary Angioedema and is not indicated in pulmonary hypertension.

Option 3. Labetalol → A non-selective beta-blocker and alpha-blocker combination, primarily used for hypertension and arrhythmias, but not for pulmonary hypertension.

Option 4. Sodium nitroprusside → A potent vasodilator, often used in hypertensive emergencies, but not a first-line treatment for primary pulmonary hypertension.

 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2129.

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl, born to Punjabi parents, has had a history of pallor since 3 months of age. She was transfused with one unit of blood at 5 months of age. She now presents with worsening pallor. On examination, she has hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory findings show hemoglobin of 3.8 g/dl, MCV of 68, MCH of 19, and a peripheral smear revealing erythroid hyperplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's history and laboratory findings strongly suggest beta-thalassemia major, a hemoglobinopathy that typically presents in the first year of life with severe anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and the need for blood transfusions.

Key features that point towards beta-thalassemia major:

  • Severe anemia with low MCV and low MCH (microcytic, hypochromic anemia).

  • Erythroid hyperplasia on peripheral smear, indicating the bone marrow's response to anemia by increasing erythropoiesis.

  • Hepatosplenomegaly, which is common due to extramedullary hematopoiesis in thalassemia.

  • Increased transfusion requirements (the child received a blood transfusion at 5 months of age), which is characteristic of beta-thalassemia major.

     

    Other Options:

  • 1. Sickle cell anemia: This usually presents with painful crises, splenic sequestration, or stroke in the first few years of life, but the patient’s microcytic anemia with hypochromia and erythroid hyperplasia is more consistent with thalassemia.

  • 2. Alpha-thalassemia: While alpha-thalassemia can present with anemia and splenomegaly, it is more commonly associated with hemoglobin H disease or alpha-thalassemia major, which would show more severe manifestations of anemia. However, beta-thalassemia fits better with the clinical picture.

  • 4. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD): G6PD deficiency typically presents with hemolysis following triggers like infections or certain medications, but it does not usually cause severe anemia requiring frequent transfusions at such a young age.


Beta-Thalassemia:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 761, 762.

questions.text: Two patients, A and B, both 58 years old. Patient A has diabetes, while Patient B does not. Which of the following complications is Patient A 100 times more likely to develop compared to Patient B?
questions.solution:
• The incidence of lower limb ischemia is increased 100 times in patients with diabetes due to the hardened and narrowed arteries caused by high levels of sugar present in the bloodstream.
  • The narrowing of the arteries reduces the amount of blood that flows to the lower limbs, thereby increasing the risk of decreased oxygen levels to the limbs and leading to tissue damage.
  • The high blood sugar levels also make the blood more viscous, causing it to flow more slowly and resulting in greater chance of a blockage and lower limb ischemia.
  • Diabetes increases the likelihood of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and its complications, including gangrene and amputation, compared to non-diabetic patients. This risk is approximately 100 times higher in diabetic individuals for developing lower limb ischemia.
  • Risk of other complications like Myocardial infarction, Cerebrovascular stroke & Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency also increases, but not as much as Lower limb ischemia.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3127.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of benign intracranial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Proptosis, which refers to the bulging of the eyes, is not a feature of benign intracranial hypertension. It is more commonly associated with conditions like thyroid eye disease (Graves' disease), not with increased intracranial pressure.

Benign Intracranial Hypertension:  (a.k.a Pseudotumor cerebri)
  • Adult idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is a rare condition of unknown cause, which results in raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • Young obese women are most commonly affected, although rarely it may occur in men.
  • Patients first experience headaches, diplopia (typically from CN VI palsy), and unaltered mental status.
  • A diagnosis of IIH requires CSF opening pressure greater than 250 mmCSF
  • Key distinguishing features of IIH include normal brain imaging (such as a CT or MRI) and normal-sized ventricles, helping to rule out other causes of raised ICP.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with generalized fatigue, bone pain, and muscle weakness. Lab results reveal elevated serum phosphate and low serum calcium. Except for__________, all of the following result in secondary hyperparathyroidism.
questions.solution:
Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism i.e. hyperparathyroidism due to other underlying diseases:
  • i. Chronic Renal Failure
  • ii. Malabsorption syndrome
  • iii. Vitamin D deficiency

  • Renal failure leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism due to impaired phosphate excretion and reduced active vitamin D production, causing a decrease in calcium levels, which stimulates parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion.

  • Vitamin D deficiency can also cause secondary hyperparathyroidism as low calcium levels due to inadequate vitamin D leads to increased PTH secretion.

  • GI malabsorption (e.g., celiac disease, Crohn's disease) may result in calcium and vitamin D deficiency, which can also trigger secondary hyperparathyroidism.

However, parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism, not secondary, because it results in excessive PTH production independently of calcium or phosphate levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3172-3174.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency room with high-grade fever, impaired sensorium, and suspicion of meningococcal meningitis.Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical therapy option?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ceftriaxone

Ceftriaxone is the recommended first-line antibiotic for the empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against Neisseria meningitidis and provides good coverage against other common bacteria causing meningitis.

  • It has excellent penetration into the central nervous system, making it an appropriate choice for treating meningitis.
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam (option 2) is not typically used as the first-line therapy for meningococcal meningitis. It has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes, but it is not as effective against Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Penicillin G (option 3) used to be the drug of choice for treating meningococcal meningitis, but resistance to penicillin has become increasingly common. Ceftriaxone is now preferred due to its broader spectrum and better efficacy.
  • Cotrimoxazole (option 4) is not a recommended first-line therapy for meningococcal meningitis. It may have some activity against Neisseria meningitidis, but other antibiotics like ceftriaxone are more effective and commonly used.




 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition , Page no 1104.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with symptoms following a traumatic injury to his spinal cord. He exhibits weakness, sensory loss, and other neurological deficits. Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Contralateral dorsal column involvement.

Brown-Séquard syndrome is a spinal cord injury that affects one side of the spinal cord i.e Hemisection of spinal cord, leading to specific features:



Dorsal column involvement is usually on the same side as the lesion, not contralateral. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3446, 3447.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is dizzy and has had palpitations for two hours. When being admitted, SBP was 70 mmHg. A quick ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
From the information in the question, most probable diagnosis is PSVT.
 
  • In case of hemodynamically unstable patient, QRS synchronous Direct Current Cardioversion should be done.
  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is characterised by bursts of faster-than-normal heart rate.
  • Most prevalent from the second to the fourth decade of life Women > Men ( in case of AVNRT )
  • Adenosine or Verapamil are considered in stable patients.
  • IV fluids can support BP, but are not definitive for unstable tachycardia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1894, 1898.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man had a history of fall along with one episode of vomiting, following which he had certain memory disturbances. On evaluation at a nearby hospital, he was found to have anterograde amnesia. Which of the following structures are most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Hippocampus
Anterograde amnesia is the inability to create new memories after an event that caused amnesia, leading to a partial or complete inability to recall the recent past , while long term memories from before the event remain intact. 

Anterograde amnesia can occur from damage caused to the structures involving the Papez circuit.

The hippocampus is particularly vulnerable to trauma, hypoxia, and ischemia, and is central in cases of memory loss after head injury.

PAPEZ CIRCUIT



Other options: 

  • The internal capsule is involved in motor and sensory pathways.

  • The insular cortex is linked to emotional and autonomic functions.

  • The pedunculopontine nucleus is associated with gait and arousal—not memory.



Reference: Bradley  Neurology in clinical practice, 8th edition, Chapter 7 page 63

choices.text: Aortic valve balloon dilation to prevent further worsening

questions.text: An 11-minute workout is being performed by a 50-year-old man with aortic stenosis as per Bruce's protocol. Fatigue forced the end of the exercise. At rest, his peak systolic gradient across the aortic valve was 60 mmHg. What kind of care is ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Aortic valve replacement

The patient in question has asymptomatic aortic stenosis but develops symptoms on exercise (abnormal/positive exercise test).
