Also the presence of mean pressure gradient of 60 mm Hg puts this patient into the category of  Severe Aortic Stenosis. Since the patient in question has 'Very Severe AS' and 'Abnormal Stress Testing' he should be considered for surgical intervention in the form of Aortic Valve Replacement (AVR).


AVR is the definitive treatment for symptomatic severe AS. According to current AHA/ACC guidelines:

Symptomatic patients with a peak gradient >40 mmHg (or mean gradient >40 mmHg) or valve area <1.0 cm² are class I indications for valve replacement.

Other options: 

  • Medical management

    • Not definitive in symptomatic severe AS

    • No medical therapy halts or reverses AS progression

  • Balloon valvuloplasty

    • Temporary relief, often reserved for bridge to surgery or non-surgical candidates

    • Not durable in adults

  • Coronary angiography

    • May be done pre-operatively, but not the primary management step


Management of Aortic Stenosis is summarised below:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1982, 1983.

questions.text: Identify the ECG
questions.solution:
The ECG Shown Above Shows progressively increasing PR intervals (5 small box-> 8->10 small boxes) culminating in a non conducted P wave and dropped beat.  This is seen in 2nd Degree AV block: Mobitz type I heart block aka Wenckebach phenomenon.

         Causes: 

  • Increased vagal tone

  • Beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin

  • Inferior MI (due to RCA involvement of AV node)

  • Post-surgical AV node injury

    Clinical scenario: 

  • Often asymptomatic

  • May present with dizziness, syncope, or bradycardia

  • Common in young athletes, during sleep, or with high vagal tone



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1877, 1881.

questions.text:
During a malaria surveillance study in an endemic region, several entomological and parasitological parameters are being monitored to assess transmission dynamics. Which of the following are considered malarial vector indices?
a. Human blood index
b. Biting density 
c. Slide positivity rate
d. Inoculation rate
questions.solution:
Malarial Vector indices
 
  • The percentage of freshly fed female anopheline mosquitoes whose stomachs contain human blood is known as the human blood index. It reveals the anthrophilism's level.
  • The average number of anopheline bites per day per person is known as the man biting rate (biting density). Standardized vector catch on human bait is used to determine it.
  • Inoculation rate: This is calculated by multiplying the rate of man-biting by the rate of infectious sporozoites.
  • Slide Positivity Rate (SPR): Percentage of positive malaria blood smears among those tested – not a vector index; it is a parasitological index used in epidemiological surveillance.
  • Mosquito density: This term is typically represented as the quantity of mosquitoes caught per hour of labour.
  • The percentage of female anopheles with one sporozoite in their saliva is known as the sporozoite rate.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 307.

questions.text: 4 vials of oral polio vaccine are given below —which one can be used from left to right with the left one being 1 and the right most being 4?
questions.solution:
Vaccines 1 and 2 can be used.

Concept of VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor) - It measures the amount of heat that has been exposed to the vial of vaccine

Interpretation:

  • If inner square is lighter than outer circle → vaccine is usable.

  • If inner square is same or darker than outer circle → vaccine must be discarded.

    Key points:

  • VVM is not affected by freezing, only by heat.

  • VVM is WHO-approved and used in all UNICEF vaccine procurement.

  • VVM helps reduce vaccine wastage and ensures safety.

  • Not all vaccines need VVM (e.g., lyophilized vaccines after reconstitution).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 122.

questions.text: Two doctors independently examined 200 chest X-rays (CXR), and the Kappa statistic was calculated to be 0.71. Based on this value, what is the inference?
questions.solution:
The Kappa statistic is a measure of inter-rater agreement or reliability that adjusts for the possibility of chance agreement. The interpretation of Kappa values is as follows:

Kappa Coefficent -
0.8-1.0- Perfect
0.61-0.8 - Good
0.41-0.60- Moderate
0.21-0.4- Fair agreement
0.1-0.20- Slight agreement.

Reference: McHugh ML. Interrater reliability: the kappa statistic. Biochem Med (Zagreb). 2012;22(3):276-82. PMID: 23092060; PMCID: PMC3900052.

questions.text: A laboratory reports that the mean hemoglobin value in a sample of 2000 individuals is 13.5 gm/dL, with the distribution following a normal curve. What proportion of people are likely to have hemoglobin levels higher than 13.5 gm/dL?
questions.solution:
In a population with a normal distribution, the mean, median, and mode are all the same.

As a result, the median here is also 13.5, dividing the population into two equal halves.
As a result, 50% will be on either side of 13.5.
Hence, the percentage of people with hemoglobin levels higher than 13.5 gm is 50.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant receives their routine vaccinations as part of a national immunization program. A few days later, the infant presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and lethargy. Ultrasound reveals evidence of intussusception. Which vaccine is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus vaccine
 
  • The main cause of severe diarrhoea in young infants is rotavirus infections, which are prevented by the rotavirus vaccine.
  • After it was determined that the vaccination may have increased the risk of intussusception, or intestinal obstruction, in one of every 12,000 vaccinated infants, the vaccine was withdrawn off the market.
  • Intussusception has been associated with the rotavirus vaccine, particularly in infants under 1 year of age. The condition involves a portion of the intestine sliding into an adjacent part, causing obstruction and ischemia. The rotavirus vaccine, particularly the first dose, has been shown to have a slight increased risk of intussusception in some studies.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 130.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic in a malaria-endemic region with complaints of intermittent fever, chills, and fatigue for the past three days. You suspect uncomplicated malaria and initiate treatment. As part of public health efforts in your region, you are involved in implementing strategies aligned with the Roll Back Malaria (RBM) initiative. Which of the following is NOT a key component of the Roll Back Malaria strategy?
questions.solution:
The Roll Back Malaria (RBM) partnership, launched by WHO, focuses on integrated and sustainable strategies for malaria control. These include:

  • Promoting insecticide-treated nets (ITNs)

  • Training healthcare workers

  • Improving access to effective treatment

  • Strengthening health systems

Developing new insecticides, while important in the broader research community, is not a direct operational strategy under RBM, which emphasizes use of existing, proven interventions.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 314.

questions.text: According to a study, pure vegetarians had a lower incidence of colon cancer than non-vegetarians, and this led researchers to the conclusion that beta-carotene is protective against cancer. This may not be the case, since vegetarian subjects may be eating a high-fiber diet that lowers their risk of developing cancer. This is an illustration of:
questions.solution:
A confounding factor is a variable that influences both the dependent variable and independent variable, causing a spurious association. In this case, dietary fiber may be the actual protective factor, not beta-carotene, but since vegetarians consume both, the effect is mistakenly attributed to beta-carotene.

Other options: 

Multifactorial causation: A condition caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.
Example: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is influenced by hypertension, diabetes, smoking, high cholesterol, genetic predisposition, and sedentary lifestyle.
No single cause, but multiple risk factors together increase disease risk.


Causal association: A direct cause-effect relationship between an exposure and outcome.
Example: Smoking causes lung cancer.
Untreated hypertension causes stroke.
Exposure is proven to cause the disease, not just associated with it.

Common association: Two variables seem linked, but it's due to a third common cause or seasonal/event factor, not true causation.
Example: People who drink cold drinks often get sore throats. But the actual reason is: People drink cold drinks more in summer, and viral infections are also common in summer due to heat exposure and dehydration. So, drinking cold drinks and sore throat are commonly associated, but one does not cause the other.
The association is coincidental or based on a third factor.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 79.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a rural community presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and pallor. Stool examination reveals the presence of hookworm eggs, and the family lives in an area with poor sanitation and limited access to clean water. As part of the national deworming program, the Chandler Index is used to assess the intensity of hookworm infestation in the community. Which of the following is the least appropriate use of the Chandler Index in this case?
questions.solution:
Chandler’s index is the average number of eggs of hookworm per gram of stools.

Applications
  • Chandler's index is used in epidemiological studies of hookworm disease.
  • By this index, worm loads in different population groups can be compared, and also the degree of reduction of egg output after mass treatment.
  • The impact of control program can also be assessed by the index.
There is no clinical significance of the Chandler Index with respect to individual case severity or prognosis. 
For that, other clinical tools, such as hemoglobin levels or stool egg counts, would be more appropriate.
Hence the option (1) is the answer.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 286.

choices.text: 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of Folic acid daily once
60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of Folic acid weekly once
60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of Folic acid daily once
60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid weekly once

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of fatigue. Her dietary history reveals a vegetarian diet, and she lives in a region with a high prevalence of iron-deficiency anemia. The healthcare provider decides to initiate iron and folic acid supplementation as part of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program. What is the appropriate dosage of IFA tablets for this teenage girl under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program?
questions.solution:
Dose of IFA tablet for adolescent girl under Anemia Mukt Bharat is 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid weekly once.

 Doses of IFA tablet for various age groups under Anaemia Mukt Bharat:
  • 6-60 months : 20mg of elemental iron and 100mcg of folic acid
  • 5-10 years : 45mg of elemental iron and 400mcg of folic acid
  • 10-19 years : 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid
  • Pregnant and lactating women : 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid
  • Women of reproductive age : 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 533.

choices.text: EBM depends on clinical model and decisions analysis to base its recommendations
EBM objectively evaluates the quality of clinical research by critical assessment techniques reported by researchers in publications

The strongest argument for the therapeutic intervention is systemic review or meta-analysis of triple blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trials with allocation concealment and complete follow-up involving a homogenous population of patients or medical disorders
The weakest argument is the opinion of experts or medical boards

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Evidence Based Medicine (EBM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: EBM depends on clinical model and decisions analysis to base its recommendations

Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) does not primarily depend on clinical models and decision analysis. While decision analysis can be part of the process, EBM primarily relies on the best available clinical evidence, such as systematic reviews, meta-analyses, and randomized controlled trials, to inform medical decisions. It focuses on integrating the best available evidence with clinical expertise and patient values, rather than purely relying on clinical models or decision analysis alone.

The principle of evidence-based medicine (EBM) is that actual evidence, rather than opinion, must be the primary scientific basis for making clinical decisions; different types of evidence are judged to be of different value.

Other options: 

  • Option 2: EBM does evaluate the quality of clinical research using critical appraisal techniques. It assesses studies for bias, methodology, and the strength of evidence.

  • Option 3: The strongest argument in EBM for therapeutic interventions does involve systematic reviews or meta-analyses of high-quality studies like randomized controlled trials (RCTs). These provide the most comprehensive and robust evidence.

  • Option 4: Expert opinion is indeed the weakest form of evidence in EBM because it is subjective and not as rigorous as data derived from systematic reviews or RCTs.


Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 61.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes screening for a disease that has a test with high sensitivity and specificity. Which of the following factors influences the positive predictive value (PPV) of the test, along with its sensitivity and specificity?
questions.solution:
• PPV =Sensitivity x Prevalence/[ Sensitivity × Prevalence + 1( - Specificity) × (I - Prevalence)],
    thus PPV, is a function of sensitivity, specificity and prevalence.
 
  • While the sensitivity and specificity of a test depend only on the characteristics of the test itself, predictive values vary according to the prevalence (or underlying probability) of the disease. Thus, predictive values cannot be determined without knowing the prevalence of the disease—they are not qualities of the test per se, but are a function of the test’s characteristics and of the setting in which it is being used.
  • The higher the prevalence of a disease in the population, the higher the PPV and the lower the NPV of a test for it.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 76.

choices.text: Prior probability of SLE; sensitivity and specificity of each test
Incidence of SLE and predictive value of each test
Relative risk of SLE in this patient

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Based on clinical suspicion, you prescribe six diagnostic tests. Out of these, two tests come back negative, while four are positive. You now want to determine the likelihood that the patient actually has SLE, considering the results. What do you need to know in order to calculate the probability of SLE at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Prior probability of SLE; sensitivity and specificity of each test

In the given question, 6 tests have been performed on a person who has been clinically diagnosed as having SLE.

2 tests gave negative results and 4 tests gave positive results.
In the question, the probability of SLE at the present time has been asked, that is the YIELD that has been asked.

YIELD – It is defined as the amount of previously unrecognised disease that is getting diagnosed as a result of screening tests.
It depends on the following factors :-
  • Sensitivity of the test
  • Specificity of the test
  • Prevalence of the disease/ probability of having the disease
  • Participation of individuals in the detection program.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 70, 71.

questions.text: You are working as a public health officer in a community where trachoma is prevalent. The community has implemented the SAFE strategy for controlling trachoma, a leading cause of preventable blindness. Which of the following is not a component of the SAFE strategy for trachoma?
questions.solution:
SAFE strategy, which has been endorsed by the WHO, in an effort to avoid trachoma infections and blindness. It includes:
  • Surgery (Tertiary prevention), 
  • Antibiotic use (Secondary prevention), 
  • Facial cleanliness/hygiene (Primary prevention)
  • Environmental changes (Primordial prevention)
For better understanding, 

The SAFE strategy stands for:

  • Surgery for individuals with entropion (inward-turning eyelids) to prevent scarring of the cornea.

  • Antibiotics (usually azithromycin) for mass treatment to reduce the infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • Facial hygiene initiatives to reduce the transmission of bacteria, especially among children, by promoting regular face washing.

  • Environmental improvements (like access to clean water and sanitation) to reduce transmission vectors.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 357.

questions.text: As a Primary Health Center (PHC) medical officer, you are tasked with managing a mass anemia prophylaxis program for a rural community. Which of the following regimens would you most likely recommend for mass anemia prophylaxis in this community?
questions.solution:
For mass anemia prophylaxis, Ferrous sulfate (FeSO4) is commonly recommended. It is a widely used and cost-effective iron supplement that helps prevent and treat iron deficiency anemia.

  • Option 1 (Ferrous sulfate): This is the most commonly used regimen for mass anemia prophylaxis because it provides a standard dose of iron, is well-tolerated, and is inexpensive.

  • Option 2 (FeSO4, Vitamin C, Folate, Vitamin B12): While this combination could be useful in certain settings (especially for people with multiple deficiencies), it is not typically recommended for general mass anemia prophylaxis in a public health program.

  • Option 3 (Ferrous fumarate): This is another form of iron supplementation, but ferrous sulfate is preferred because it is more widely available and cost-effective.

  • Option 4 (Injection iron sucrose): This is used in patients with more severe anemia or those who cannot tolerate oral iron, but it is not recommended for mass prophylaxis due to its cost and the requirement for administration by healthcare professionals.

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 775.

choices.text: Reduce by 2/3rd, the under-five mortality by the year 1990-2015

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the MDGs?
questions.solution:
• The Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) were eight international development goals for the year 2015 that had been established following the Millennium Summit of the United Nations in 2000, following the adoption of the United Nations Millennium Declaration.
  • True about MDG is a) reduce by 2/3rd the under five mortality by year 1990-2012
  • One of the targets of Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 4 was to reduce under-five mortality by two-thirds between 1990 and 2015. This goal was part of efforts to improve child health globally.
Other options: 
 

  • Option 2: The MDG related to HIV/AIDS aimed to halt and begin to reverse the spread of HIV/AIDS, but not specifically to halve its prevalence by 2015.

  • Option 3: MDG 5 aimed to reduce maternal mortality by three-quarters, not 50%.

  • Option 4: The goal for hunger and poverty aimed to halve the proportion of people living on less than $1.25 a day, not reduce hunger and poverty by one-fourth.

    PICTORIAL REPRESENATATION OF MDGs

     

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 28.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with endometrial cancer has been treated with external beam radiation to the entire pelvis. Which of the following organs is radiosensitive to the greatest extent in the pelvic area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ovary

According to law of Bergonie and Tribondeau, radiosensitivity is directly proportional to mitosis and inversely proportional to differentiation.

The tolerance dose for Ovaries is the least.

  • Ovary= 2-3 Gy
  • Vagina= 90 Gy
  • Bladder = 65 Gy
  • Rectum= 60 Gy
Summary of radiosensitivity of various tissues: 



Remember- Most common organ affected due to radiation is skin. Among all the layers, Stratum basale is the most affected due to presence of actively dividing cells.


Reference: Perez & Brady's Principles and Practice of Radiation Oncology, 6th edition, Page no 65.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with decreased vision and is found to have a punched-out lesion on the retina during a fundoscopic examination. Punched-out lesion in retina is caused by all except?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 3: Posterior staphyloma.

Punched-out lesions in the retina are typically seen in conditions that involve inflammation or developmental abnormalities. Let's review the given options:

  1. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis infection can cause punched lesions in the retina. It is a common cause of focal retinochoroiditis.

  2. Congenital rubella: Congenital rubella infection can lead to a triad of findings known as the "congenital rubella syndrome," which includes cataracts, deafness, and retinopathy. The retinopathy in congenital rubella can present with punched lesions.

  3. Posterior staphyloma: Posterior staphyloma is a structural abnormality of the eyeball where there is a bulging or elongation of the posterior segment. It is not associated with punched lesions in the retina.

  4. Choroidal coloboma: Choroidal coloboma is a congenital defect in the choroid layer of the eye. It can be associated with punched lesions in the retina.

    Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 150,170,546 .

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a conjunctival infection that progressed to corneal perforation. A Gram stain of the ocular discharge reveals Gram-negative coccoid organisms. The culture further shows small translucent colonies that are oxidase-positive. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Infection with Gram negative diplococci forming small translucent colonies, which is oxidase positive is indicative of Neisseria gonorrheae.
It can cause conjunctivitis, which in severe cases can progress to corneal perforation.
  • Most common cause of Acute purulent/ Hyperacute conjunctivitis is N. gonorrhoeae > N. meningitidis
  • Moraxella is also a gram negative, oxidase positive cocci but Moraxella catarrhalis occur more commonly in young children and may occur in institutional epidemics. Moraxella axenfeld is the causative organism of Angular conjunctivitis.
  • Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter are gram negative bacilli.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive visual disturbances over the past year. She reports difficulty with night vision and sees halos around lights. She is diagnosed to have some sort of corneal dystrophy. Usually, corneal dystrophies are:
questions.solution:
• Corneal dystrophies are typically genetic, primary, and bilateral conditions affecting the cornea, often with a gradual, progressive course.
  • They are not associated with systemic disease, and they usually affect both eyes, symmetrically.
  • Common types include epithelial, stromal, and endothelial dystrophies, which often lead to vision impairment but do not cause inflammation.
  • Corneal dystrophies are generally inherited in an autosomal dominant or recessive pattern. Common examples include Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy, granular dystrophy, and lattice dystrophy. The symptoms, such as visual impairment or clouding of the cornea, generally appear gradually, and vision loss can be progressive if left untreated.




Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 186.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with a corneal ulcer. After evaluation, the patient is prescribed eye drops to manage the condition. Which of the following is not typically used for corneal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Fluorometholone is a steroid eye drop primarily used to reduce inflammation in various eye conditions, including uveitis and allergic conjunctivitis. However, in the case of corneal ulcers, steroids like Fluorometholone are generally avoided unless there is no active infection, as they can worsen infections by suppressing the immune response.

  • Chloramphenicol: This is an antibiotic used in treating bacterial corneal ulcers. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

  • Methylcellulose: This is a viscosity agent used to provide lubrication for dry eyes. It does not treat infections but can help in maintaining eye moisture.

  • Olapatadine: This is an antihistamine used in the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis and may be used for allergic-related eye symptoms, but it does not treat corneal infections.

In summary, Fluorometholone is not typically used for corneal ulcers due to its potential to exacerbate infections, making it an inappropriate choice for treating corneal ulcers in this case.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 229.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of non-infectious uveitis is being assessed for prophylaxis to prevent flare-ups of the condition. She is enrolled in the LUMINATE program. Which of the following drugs is currently used for the prophylaxis of non-infectious uveitis in the LUMINATE program?
questions.solution:
The LUMINATE program (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) is a clinical trial designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of voclosporin, a novel calcineurin inhibitor, in patients with non-infectious uveitis. Voclosporin has been shown to be effective in the prophylaxis and management of non-infectious uveitis, particularly in preventing flare-ups by controlling inflammation and immune response.

  • Methotrexate: While methotrexate is commonly used in the management of non-infectious uveitis, especially for chronic or refractory cases, it was not the focus of the LUMINATE program.

  • Infliximab: This TNF-alpha inhibitor is also used in the treatment of uveitis, particularly in cases resistant to other therapies, but it is not the drug being studied in the LUMINATE program.

  • Cyclosporine: Although cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used for various autoimmune diseases, it is not the primary drug studied for uveitis in the LUMINATE program.

Therefore, voclosporin is the correct drug used in the LUMINATE program for the prophylaxis of non-infectious uveitis (as a steroid-sparing therapy).





Reference: Anglade, Eddy et al. “A new agent for the treatment of noninfectious uveitis: rationale and design of three LUMINATE (Lux Uveitis Multicenter Investigation of a New Approach to Treatment) trials of steroid-sparing voclosporin.” Clinical ophthalmology (Auckland, N.Z.) vol. 2,4 (2008): 693-702. doi:10.2147/opth.s2452

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a 10-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of blurred vision and sudden onset of floaters in both eyes over the past few days. On examination, you observe vitreous hemorrhage. What's the underlying reason?
questions.solution:
Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina). In an affected individual, these blood vessels become weak and easily damaged, which can lead to bleeding and vision loss.
  • Neovascularization is the formation of new blood vessels produced in response to hypoxia, or low oxygen levels, in the retinal tissue.
  • Neovascularization of the disc, or disc neovascularization, is a common finding in diabetic retinopathy and usually appears as a ring of small, dilated blood vessels around the optic disc.
  • The new blood vessels are often fragile and bleed easily, leading to vitreous haemorrhage, a condition in which the vitreous chamber of the eye becomes filled with blood.
Other options: 

  • Posterior retinal detachment (option 2): Although this condition can cause visual disturbances, it is not typically associated with diabetic retinopathy or vitreous hemorrhage in this context.

  • Central retinal vein occlusion (option 3): While this can cause retinal hemorrhages, it is not commonly associated with vitreous hemorrhage in the early stages.

  • Trauma to central retinal artery (option 4): This leads to central retinal artery occlusion, typically causing sudden vision loss but does not cause diabetic retinopathy or vitreous hemorrhage.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 545, 546.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was found to have a refractive error of -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees. What kind of Astigmatism does the child have?
questions.solution:
Astigmatism is classified based on the orientation of the cylinder (the astigmatic power). The orientation of the cylinder axis plays a crucial role in the classification:

  • With the rule astigmatism: The cylindrical power is along the vertical meridian (90°), meaning the vertical axis is more curved than the horizontal one.

  • Against the rule astigmatism: The cylindrical power is along the horizontal meridian (180°), meaning the horizontal axis is more curved than the vertical one.

  • Mixed astigmatism: This involves a combination of positive and negative power in the different meridians (one meridian has a plus power and another has a minus power).

  • Simple astigmatism: There is only one meridian with astigmatism.

In the case of this child, the -2D cylindrical at 180° and -1D spherical implies that the vertical meridian (90°) is more powerful than the horizontal meridian, which aligns with With the Rule Astigmatism.



Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page. No: 42, 43.
